All front passenger doors must be fitted with internal operating controls which are accessible from the adjacent seating position (see Note 4).
All aperture covers must secure in the fully closed position.
The vehicle must be fitted with a horn.
The horn must be secure.
The horn must emit a continuous uniform sound.
The horn must perform to an equivalent level of an EC Type Approved vehicle.
The vehicle must have an offside exterior mirror fitted.
An interior mirror must be fitted.
The vehicle must have an nearside exterior mirror fitted. (if the interior rear view mirror gives no view to the rear or the rear window is less than 70% light transmittance)
All obligatory mirrors/CMS must be securely mounted to the vehicle, to ensure that the field of view does not change.
All mirrors must be adjustable.
Obligatory mirrors/CMS must be mounted so as to prevent the driver misinterpreting the image because of vibration.
All mirrors must have an acceptable approval marking or have equivalent characteristics to a mirror approved for use on a vehicle of the same category as follows:
• The reflective surface must be encased in a protective housing.

• surfaces contactable by a 165mm sphere (interior) or a 100mm sphere (exterior) must have a radius of curvature of at least 2.5mm – except for fixing holes or recesses less than 12mm wide, which must be blunted.
An interior mirror must be a minimum of 40mm high by 80mm long .
An exterior mirror must be a minimum of 40mm high and 70mm long, and be able to incorporate a measurement parallel to the height of the rectangle at least 70mm in length within the lens.
The interior mirror must be adjustable from the normal driving position (see Note 8).

The mirror fitted to the driver’s side of a vehicle must be adjustable from the driving seat while the door is closed, although the window may be open (see Note 8). The mirror may, however, be locked in position from the outside. Alternatively, if knocked out of alignment, it must be capable of being returned to its former position without the need for adjustment.
An obligatory mirror or CMS must provide the required field of view.
CMS must be approved to the requirements of UNECE Regulation 46.04 paragraph 6.2.2; documentary evidence will be required.
The vehicle as presented must be accompanied by satisfactory evidence of compliance with the required standard for “ Braking “.

The vehicle must be fitted with a service braking system that is completely independent of the control of the parking brake, capable of functioning on all wheels by a single means of operation, which will gradually increase or reduce the braking force through action of the control.

The ‘service’ braking system must be capable of being operated from the driving seat, whilst keeping both hands on the steering wheel. This does not apply to the controls for use by a disabled driver, providing the adaptation allows him/her to control the steering at all times while operating either braking system.
The ‘service’ braking system must be capable of being operated to slow down the vehicle when it is moving in a forward or reverse direction.

The vehicle must be fitted with a split (dual) circuit brake system with each part of the system operating on at least two wheels (one on each side), capable of operating in the event of a failure of the service brake or its power assistance.
The vehicle must be fitted with a secondary system, capable of operating in the event of a failure of the service brake or its power assistance.
The ‘parking’ braking system must be capable of being operated from the driving seat, whilst keeping one hand on the steering wheel.
The ‘parking’ braking system must be capable of being operated and released whether the vehicle is stationary or moving.
The ‘parking’ braking system must be capable of being operated on all wheels of at least one axle enabling the vehicle to be held on an up or down gradient even in the absence of the driver.

The ‘parking’ braking system must be capable of being operated using a control which is independent of the service brake, and once applied capable of being maintained in the ‘on’ position solely by mechanical means.
The brake control must be capable of being operated easily from the driving position without obstruction or abnormal hand/foot position and that the pedal (where fitted) has an anti-slip provision.
All service brake controls must operate in the same direction as the forces created when the vehicle is in forward direction.
A brake control, actuating linkage or associated component must be fully accessible for maintenance purposes.
A brake control, actuating linkage or associated component must be complete, so that it functions correctly.
A brake control, actuating linkage or associated component must be of adequate strength so as not to be likely to fail prematurely.
A brake control, actuating linkage or associated component must be made of a material sufficiently durable so as not to be likely to fail prematurely.
A brake control, actuating linkage or associated component must not be obstructed in its travel nor foul parts of the vehicle.
A brake control, actuating linkage or associated component mounting/bracket must be of adequate strength so as not to be likely to fail prematurely.
A brake control, actuating linkage or associated component mounting/bracket must be secure to the vehicle structure.
A brake control, actuating linkage or associated component mounting/bracket securing method must be of adequate strength so as not to be likely to fail prematurely.
A brake control, actuating linkage or associated component pivot bearing/bush must be of adequate strength so as not to be likely to fail prematurely.
A brake control, actuating linkage or associated component pivot bearing/bush must be secure such that it is unlikely to become displaced.
Any brake control, actuating linkage or associated component pivot/linkage pins must be present and secure.
Any brake control, actuating linkage or associated component locking/retaining devices must be present and secure.
With the brake control fully applied there must be sufficient reserve travel.
The brake control must not creep down while it is held under pressure.
There must not be an indication of ‘sponginess’ when the brake control is operated, indicating air in the system.
When the brake control is applied (following vacuum depletion) and the engine started a dip must be felt, indicating that vacuum assistance is working satisfactorily.
On a full power hydraulic braking system a warning device must be fitted, operative, and visible or audible to the driver, including in darkness.
All brake mechanical components must be secure, with relevant securing bolts, locking devices, retaining device etc present and secure.
A brake assembly on a FRONT axle of a vehicle must incorporate an automatic means of compensating for friction material wear.
A brake assembly on a REAR axle of a vehicle must incorporate an automatic or manual means of compensating for friction material wear.
The brake friction surfaces must have sufficient capacity to dissipate heat and prevent fade.
It must be possible to easily check the wear on service brake linings, from the outside or underside of the vehicle.
All braking controls must apply and release the relevant brakes at a rate comparable to that of an approved system.
It must not be possible to manually adjust braking rates between axles.

Vehicles fitted with adjustable twin master cylinders that have been rendered inoperable by mechanical means to comply with RS 26 of Section 09B of the IVA N1 Inspection Manual, must have a label affixed on the master cylinder or the immediate vicinity with legible text as detailed in note 6 of that section.
The service braking system must act on braking surfaces permanently connected to the wheels through components of adequate strength.
A parking brake lever, actuating linkage, cable or associated component must be complete so that it functions correctly.
A parking brake lever, actuating linkage, cable or associated component must be of adequate strength so as not to be likely to fail prematurely.
A parking brake lever, actuating linkage, cable or associated component must be made of a material sufficiently durable so as not to be likely to fail prematurely.
A parking brake lever, actuating linkage, cable or associated component must not be obstructed in its travel nor foul parts of the vehicle.
A parking brake lever, actuating linkage, cable or associated component mounting / bracket must be secure to the vehicle structure.
A parking brake lever, actuating linkage, cable or associated component mounting / bracket securing method must be of adequate strength so as not to be likely to fail prematurely.
A parking brake lever, actuating linkage, cable or associated component pivot bearing / bush must be of adequate strength so as not to be likely to fail prematurely.
A parking brake lever, actuating linkage, cable or associated component pivot bearing / bush must be secure such that it is unlikely to become displaced.
A parking brake lever, actuating linkage, cable or associated component pivot / linkage pins must be present and secure.
A parking brake lever, actuating linkage, cable or associated component locking / retaining devices must be present and secure.
The parking brake ratchet pawl must engage positively with the ratchet teeth.
A hand lever operated parking brake must not disengage when the lever is knocked on each side and on the top.
A lever operated parking brake when fully applied must have reserve travel and locking positions.

An electrically operated parking brake switch must be protected from inadvertent use. As an alternative, with the ignition off, the switch must be capable of applying the brake, but must not be capable of releasing the brake.
The parking brake mechanism must incorporate a means of manual or automatic adjustment to compensate for wear.
A hydraulic and vacuum component must be complete, so that it functions correctly.
A hydraulic and vacuum component must be of adequate strength so as not to be likely to fail prematurely
A hydraulic and vacuum component must be made of a material sufficiently durable so that it is unlikely to fail prematurely.
A hydraulic and vacuum component mounting/bracket must be secure to the vehicle structure or other components.
A hydraulic and vacuum component mounting/bracket must be of adequate strength so as not to be likely to fail prematurely.
A hydraulic and vacuum component mounting/bracket securing method must be of adequate strength and unlikely to fail prematurely.
A brake pipe or hose must not be fouled by moving parts.
A brake pipe or hose must not be kinked, stretched, or twisted.
A brake pipe or hose must be adequately clipped or otherwise supported.
A brake pipe or hose must have suitable joint fittings.
A brake pipe or hose must not be exposed to excessive heat.
A hydraulic/vacuum component must not be subject to a corrosive environment and likely to fail prematurely.
Components from Hydraulic and Vacuum Systems must not leak.
A fluid reservoir filling port must be easily accessible.
A fluid reservoir cap must be present and secure.

It must be possible to check the fluid relative to the manufacturer’s specified minimum level on all brake fluid reservoirs by the actual fluid level being visible through a transparent section of the reservoir, with the minimum level marked permanently on to this section. As an alternative, a red warning lamp must be capable of illuminating when the reservoir fluid falls to the minimum level.

An indelible label must be affixed in a visible position within 100 mm of the filling ports of the fluid reservoirs to ensure that it is possible for the end user of the vehicle to identify the brake fluid used in braking system. DOT fluid references and/or the Symbols and text in table 1 in Section 09D of the IVA N1 Inspection Manual, are considered acceptable.

Where a warning lamp is provided as the only means of checking the fluid level without opening the reservoir, it must be secure, operational, visible during daylight and darkness from the driving position, and fitted with a “test facility” that enables its operation to be checked from the driving position without opening the reservoir.

The hydraulic system must be fitted with a red warning lamp, sensitive to line pressure and capable of signalling the failure of any part of the hydraulic system as soon as the brake is applied and remaining lit as long as the failure exists (with the ignition switched on). As an alternative, the warning lamp must be sensitive to the reservoir fluid level, providing the reservoir is directly connected to supply the pressure side of the master cylinder when the piston is in the “brakes off” position, so that a failure of either part of a split system would result in a continuous draining of the reservoir fluid when the control is released.

The hydraulic system failure warning lamp must be secure, operational, visible during daylight and darkness from the driving position, identifiable (i.e. labelled in a recognised form) and fitted with a “test facility” that enables its operation to be checked from the driving position without opening the reservoir.
If the vehicle is fitted with an anti-lock braking system, all components must be present, undamaged, secure, connected and operational so that the system is likely to function as intended.

If the vehicle is fitted with an anti-lock braking system an operational warning lamp must be fitted to monitor the system, visible from the driving position, which operates when the anti-lock is energised, and extinguishes at the latest when the vehicle speed reaches 10km/h.
A low braking effort must not be recorded from any wheel, indicating clearly that the brake is not functioning correctly.
The service brake performance must be at least 50%, (of the CLW or DGW as determined to be the highest) or more than half the road wheels lock.

The secondary brake performance must be at least 25%,(of the
CLW or DGW as determined to be the highest) for:
• each half of the split system or
• the park brake if used as secondary. (see Note 7) or
• more than half the road wheels lock
A significant braking effort must not be recorded from a road wheel without application of the brakes, indicating brake bind.
There must be no evidence of severe brake grab or judder as the brake is applied.
The braking efforts at the road wheels must increase progressively at about the same rate when the service brake is applied gradually.
The braking efforts at the road wheels must reduce at about the same rate when the service brake is released gradually.
The brake pedal must return to the fully off position.
The brake effort of one wheel must not be less than 70% of the effort recorded from the other wheel on any steering axle (an axle that provides the main source of directional control of the vehicle).
The braking ratio of the axles, for all values of total brake force must be less than the friction force ratio (taking into account weight transfer) between axles in running order (see Note 1).
The calculated service efficiency with the servo depleted must be at least 25% (see Note 2).
Where a vehicle is fitted with a full power hydraulic system, the calculated service brake efficiency after four full applications must be at least 25% (see Note 3).
A low braking effort must not be recorded from any wheel, indicating clearly that the parking brake is not functioning correctly.
The parking brake performance must be at least 18%, (of the CLW or DGW as determined to be the highest) unless more than half of the wheels lock as operated by the park brake.
The service brake performance must be a minimum of 50%.
The parking brake performance must be a minimum of 18%.
When the service brake is applied the brake must be capable of progressive operation.
When the service brake is applied there must not be severe grab or judder.
When the service brake is applied the vehicle should not deviate to the left or right.
When the service brake is applied the pedal must return to the fully off position.
All wheels of the rear axle(s) must not lock prior to both wheels of the front axle.
The transmission parking brake efficiency must be at least 18%.
All wheels of the rear axle(s) must not lock prior to both wheels of the front axle.
The HT ignition system must be fitted with radio interference suppression equipment.
The trade name or mark and trade description must be present on the interference suppression equipment.
There must be a maximum of 120mm separation between trade markings on suppression cables.
A vehicle MUST be fitted with either a mechanical anti – theft device or an electronic immobiliser.
If fitted to the Vehicle, an anti – theft device must be operational.
If fitted to the Vehicle, an anti – theft device must not operate on any part of the braking system.
If an anti - theft device incorporates a mechanical part that acts upon a system used to control the vehicle, it must deactivate before the engine can be started.
If an anti - theft device incorporates a mechanical part that acts upon a system used to control the vehicle, it must be deactivated while the engine is running.

If an anti - theft device incorporates a mechanical part that acts upon a system used to control the vehicle, it must have an actuation which is a distinct and separate function from that of stopping the engine.
Where the vehicle has no mechanical anti - theft device fitted, an electronic immobiliser must be fitted.
The vehicle as presented must be accompanied by evidence of compliance for an Immobiliser.
The vehicle as presented must be accompanied by evidence of compliance where an alarm is fitted.
The vehicle as presented must be accompanied by evidence of compliance where an panic alarm is fitted.

Any part of the steering control directed towards the driver which is contactable with a sphere of 165mm diameter must have a radius of curvature of at least 2.5mm. This does not apply if the vehicle is a mass-produced vehicle and has an airbag fitted to the steering control which was fitted at the time of manufacture. However in this case all parts of the steering control must be blunted.
The steering control must be designed, constructed and fitted in such a way that it is not possible to catch the driver’s clothing or jewellery during normal driving movements.

The steering control and column assembly must provide adequate protection to the driver by absorbing energy from a driver-steering wheel impact. This is the case if the steering control has an approval (evidence may be markings or documents), or is similar to an approved steering control. The vehicle should be assessed using the material in Annex 1 of Section 14 of the IVA N1 Inspection Manual.

The vehicle and steering column assembly must be designed such that in the event of a frontal impact at 48km/h (30mph) the rearward horizontal displacement and vertical displacement of the top of the steering column and its shaft do not exceed 127mm. The vehicle should be assessed using the material in Annex 1 of Section 14 of the IVA N1 Inspection Manual.

Airbags are not permitted on vehicles which are: i. an amateur built vehicle ii. A vehicle manufactured in very low volume iii. A vehicle manufactured using parts of a registered vehicle iv. A rebuilt vehicle
The vehicle as presented must be accompanied by satisfactory evidence of compliance with the required standard for “protective steering”.
Every seat must be securely attached to the vehicle structure, or other obvious suitable load bearing parts of the vehicle.
Every seat mounting must be of adequate strength to support the loads likely to be imposed.
Each seat, seat back adjustment and seat displacement system must incorporate an automatic locking system which operates in all positions provided for normal use.

A seat fitted with a displacement device to facilitate access by passengers must be fitted with an unlocking control which is accessible from outside the vehicle when the door is open. Where the seat immediately behind the seat concerned is designated for an adult, the unlocking control must also be easily accessible from this position.
The rear parts of the seats must not have rough or sharp edges likely to increase the risk of injury to the occupants.
The vehicle must be fitted with an acceptable type of Speedometer.

A speedometer must be capable of indicating the vehicle speed in miles per hour (mph). A dial instrument must be marked at uniform intervals not exceeding 20mph for all speeds up to the maximum design speed of the vehicle (see Note 2).
The speedometer must be capable of being read at all times of the day or night.
The speedometer must not indicate a speed less than the true speed.
The speedometer must not indicate a speed that is in excess of the true speed plus the permitted tolerance in the chart in Section 17 of the IVA N1 Inspection Manual.
The in use “rest” position for the needle of a dial type must be between the Zero position and the first marked increment.
The vehicle must have an operational reverse gear which can be selected from the driving position.
The vehicle must be fitted with a manufacturer’s plate, in a conspicuous and readily accessible position.
A manufacturer's plate(s) must be fitted for each stage of a multistage build and be positioned in close proximity to each other.
The manufacturer's plate must be made of a durable material.
The manufacturer’s plate(s) must be securely attached to a part of the vehicle that will not be replaced through normal use.

The manufacturer’s plate(s) must be indelibly marked with the
manufacturer’s name
The chassis manufacturer’s plate must include the required vehicle masses as detailed in the diagram below.

All plate(s) must be indelibly marked with the Vehicle Identification Number (VIN) which matches the number marked into the vehicle structure and is displayed in the correct order inside a clearly marked rectangle (see above and Note 1).

The Stamped in VIN must be marked on the chassis, frame or other similar structure which is not easily removable, on the right hand side of the vehicle when viewed from the rear (see Notes 7, 8 & 11).
The Stamped in VIN must be placed in a clearly visible and accessible position by a method such as hammering or stamping so that it can not be obliterated or deteriorate.
The VIN number must consist of 17 digits with the information shown in a sinlge line.
Capital letters and numerals must be used for the VIN
The Vehicle Identification number on the manufacturer’s plate must be marked in characters at least 3.5mm high
There must not be any gaps between the characters for the VIN or the unique vehicle identifier number shown on the manufacturer's plate or stamped into the vehicle.
The characters on the manufacturer’s plate (with the exception of the Vehicle Identification Number) must be at least 2mm high.
The characters used for the VIN number stamped into the chassis, frame or other similar structure must be at least 3.5mm high
Use of the letter I, the letter O, the letter Q, dashes, asterisks and other special signs are not permitted.
In instances where the VIN has been changed evidence of agreement with the Approval Authority must be provided
The original complete vehicle identification number of the base vehicle must be present on the chassis.
The complete new VIN must be stamped on the chassis as near as possible to the original VIN
The last eight characters of the new VIN must be identical to the last eight characters of the base vehicle VIN.
The drivers seating position must have a minimum of 3 seat belt anchorages.
The foremost outboard passenger seating position must have a minimum of 3 seat belt anchorages.

A front centre seating position must have a minimum of:
a. 2 anchorages or
b. 3 anchorages (See note 2 in Section 19 of the IVA N1 Inspection Manual)
Rear seating positions must have a minimum of 2 anchorages if required to be fitted with seat belts.
The seat belt anchorage must be correctly located so to ensure the belt will sit correctly on the wearer.

Seats which are not intended for use when the vehicle is driven on public road must be accompanied with a pictogram or sign clearly indicating that the seat is not to be used whilst the vehicle is in motion..

The anchorage and surrounding structure must be of adequate strength to withstand the load likely to be imposed in the event of a vehicle frontal impact. Spreader plates, where fitted, must be of adequate size and radiused to 2.5mm. (see Note 4 & Annex 2)
The vehicle as presented must be accompanied by satisfactory evidence of compliance with the required standard for “Seat Belt Anchorages”.

1. The vehicle must be fitted with lamps or retro reflective material only capable of showing a white light to the front except for:
• an amber light from a direction indicator
• an amber light from a hazard beacon/warning lamp
• a yellow light from a front fog lamp
• a yellow light from a front end outline marker lamp
• an amber light from a side marker light
• a red light from a rearmost side marker or rear position lamp
• emergency vehicles only, a blue light from a warning lamp or beacon

2. The vehicle must be fitted with  lamps or retro reflective material only capable of showing a red light to the rear except for:

•  an amber light from a direction indicator
•  an amber light from a hazard beacon/warning lamp
•  a white light from a work lamp, reversing lamp, interior lamp, or a registration plate lamp
•  a yellow light from a registration plate
•  an amber light from a side marker light
•  emergency vehicles only, a blue light from a warning lamp or beacon.
•  emergency vehicles only, a yellow-green light from a retro reflective material.
The operation of any lamp must not effect any other lamp or be affected by the operation of any other lamp, unless specifically designed to do so.

4. All obligatory and optional lamps and reflectors must be securely fitted to the vehicle and not move by swivelling, deflecting or otherwise while the vehicle is in motion, except for: 

• any lamp or reflector which by design can be deflected to the side with the movement of the front wheel or wheels of the vehicle when turned for the purpose of steering the vehicle
• a headlamp for adjustment or dipping of the beam
• a headlamp which can be retracted or concealed
• a work lamp, used to illuminate a working area or the scene of an accident, breakdown or road works in the vicinity of the vehicle to which it is fitted.
All obligatory and optional lamps, reflectors and rear markers must be fitted to their correct orientation.
a. half (50%) of the apparent surface of the lamp or reflector is visible from directly in front of / behind (as appropriate) the vehicle
b. additional fully visible lamp (s) / reflectors satisfying all requirements for the above lamps / reflectors are activated / visible

c. a notice in the vehicle must inform the user that in certain positions of the movable components, other road users should be warned of the presence of the vehicle on the road (e.g. by laying out a warning triangle).
All lamps must emit light of an equivalent brightness and colour when compared to an e approved lamp of the same type.
The correct number of retro reflectors must be fitted to the vehicle.
The correct colour of retro reflectors must be fitted to the vehicle.
The retro reflectors must be positioned to meet positional requirements.
The retro reflectors must be positioned to meet the angles of visibility requirements.
The retro reflectors must be of the correct shape.
Retro reflectors must have similar characteristics when compared to an ‘e’ marked reflector.
Rear reflectors must face predominately to the rear.

sectionDescription: End Outline, Position (Side), Stop, Side Marker & Daytime Running Lights

requiredStandards.requiredStandard: The correct number of front and rear position lamps must be fitted to the vehicle.
The front and rear position lamps must be operational.
The front and rear position lamps must only emit white light to the front / red light to the rear.
The front and rear position lamps must be switched on and off by the operation of one switch.
The front and rear position lamps must must have a tell tale fitted.
The front and rear position lamps must be positioned to meet the positional requirements.
The front and rear position lamps must be positioned to meet the angles of visibility requirements.
The correct number of stop lamps must be fitted to the vehicle.
All stop lamps must be operational.
The stop lamps must only emit red light.
The stop lamps must only illuminate when the the service brake is applied, and must extinguish when the service brake is released.
The stop  lights must be so positioned so as to meet the positional requirements of Table 1 in Section 22 of the IVA N1 Inspection Manual.
The stop  lights must be so positioned so as to meet the angles of visibility requirements of Table 1 in Section 22 of the IVA N1 Inspection Manual.
Optional stop lamps must face to the rear.
The correct number of mandatory side marker lamps must be fitted to the vehicle if its length exceeds 6m.
The side marker lights must be operational.
The side marker lights must emit an amber light. (red is acceptable if within 1 metre of the rear)
The side marker lamps must be switched on and off by the operation of one switch.
The side marker lights must be positioned to meet the positional requirements of Table 1 in Section 22 of the IVA N1 Inspection Manual.
The side marker lights must be positioned to meet the angles of visibility requirements of Table 1 in Section 22 of the IVA N1 Inspection Manual.
The correct number of mandatory end outline marker lamps must be fitted to the vehicle.
The end outline marker lamps must be operational.
The end outline marker lamps must only emit red light to the rear / white light to the front.
The end outline marker lamps must be switched on and off by the operation of one switch.
The end outline marker lamps must be positioned to meet the positional requirements of Table 1 and Note 4 in Section 22 of the IVA N1 Inspection Manual.
The end outline marker lamps must be positioned to meet the angles of visibility requirements of Table 1 in Section 22 of the IVA N1 Inspection Manual.
The correct number of daytime running lamps must be fitted to the vehicle.
The daytime running lamps must be operational.
The daytime running lamps must only emit white light to the front.
The daytime running lamps must be positioned to meet the positional requirements of Table 1 in Section 22 of the IVA N1 Inspection Manual.
The daytime running lamps must be positioned to meet the angles of visibility requirements of Table 1 in Section 22 of the IVA N1 Inspection Manual.
The daytime running lamps must extinguish automatically when headlamps are operated.
The direction indicator lamps must be operational.
The correct number of direction indicator lamps must be fitted to the vehicle.
The indicators must flash at a rate of between 60 and 120 times a minute. (with all mandatory indicators working, and with the engine running)
There must be a audible or visual tell tale fitted to indicate the operation of any indicators such that would not cause confusion to the driver.
All direction indicator lamps must emit amber light.
The direction indicator lamps must be positioned to meet the positional requirements of Table 1 in Section 23 of the IVA N1 Inspection Manual.
The direction indicator lamps must be positioned to meet the angles of visibility requirements of Table 1 in Section 23 of the IVA N1 Inspection Manual.
The hazard warning lamps must operate with the ignition switched on and off.
The hazard warning device must operate all of the direction indicators simultaneously.
The hazard warning device must have a telltale warning light.
The rear registration plate lamps must be operational.
The rear registration plate lamps must be able to be switched on and off with the front and rear position lights by operating one switch.
The rear registration plate lamps must only emit white light.
The rear registration plate lamps must be positioned to sufficiently illuminate the rear registration plate (see Note 1).
All obligatory and optional headlamps must be fitted as “matched pairs”.
All headlamps must be operational.
They must be fitted in the correct orientation as would be on an approved vehicle.
All headlamps must emit a white light.
When on dip or main beam, headlamps must emit sufficient light to be able to illuminate the road in front of the vehicle.
The correct number of headlamps must be fitted to the vehicle.
Dipped beam headlamps must be positioned to meet the requirements of Table 1 in Section 25 of the IVA N1 Inspection Manual.
There must be a tell tale when the headlamps are on Main Beam.
Where the dipped beam is provided by gas discharge (HID) light sources these must remain lit when the headlamp is switched to main beam.
Vehicles fitted with Gas Discharge (HID), or LED headlamps producing the principal dipped beam must be accompanied with evidence that the light output does not exceed 2000 lumens
Vehicles fitted with Gas Discharge (HID), or LED headlamps producing the principal dipped beam must be accompanied with evidence of self-levelling and be fitted with a headlamp cleaning system
The dipped beam image ‘kick-up’ must not be to the offside.
For headlamps with centres not more than 850mm from the ground, the dipped beam image horizontal cut-off must be between the horizontal 0.5% and 2% lines, i.e. the red tolerance band.
For headlamps with centres more than 850mm from the ground, the dipped beam image horizontal cutoff must be between the horizontal 1.25% and 2.75% lines, i.e. the blue tolerance band.
The dipped beam image ‘break point’ must not be to the right of the 0% vertical line, or to the left of the vertical 2% line.
On British American headlamps, checked on main beam, the ‘hot spot’ centre must not be above the horizontal 0% line.
On British American headlamps, checked on main beam, the ‘hot spot’ centre must not be to the right of the vertical 0% line, or the left of the vertical 2% line.
On British American headlamps, checked on main beam, for headlamps where the centre is not more than 850mm from the ground, the ‘hot spot’ centre must not be below the horizontal 2% line.
On British American headlamps, checked on main beam, for headlamps where the centre is more than 850mm from the ground, the ‘hot spot’ centre must not be below the horizontal 2.75% line.
On British American headlamps, checked on main beam, when switched from main beam to dipped beam the image must “Dip” to the left.
On British American headlamps, checked on dipped beam, the upper edge of the ‘hot spot’ must not be above the horizontal 0% line.
On British American headlamps, checked on dipped beam, the upper edge of the ‘hot spot’ must not be below the horizontal 2.75% line.
On British American headlamps, checked on dipped beam, the right hand edge of the ‘hot spot’ must not be to the right of the vertical 0% line, or to the left of the vertical 2% line.
The correct number of front fog lamps must be fitted to the vehicle.
The front fog lamps must be operational.
Fog lamps must be able to be switched on only when the position lights are on and must operate independently of the dipped and main beam headlamps.
The front fog lamps must only emit white or yellow light.
The front fog lamps must be fitted with a tell tale.
Either the switch or tell tale must clearly indicate that operation relates to the front fog lights.
The front fog lamps must be positioned correctly to meet the positional requirements of Table 1 in Section 26 of the IVA N1 Inspection Manual.
The rear fog lamps must be operational.
The correct number of rear fog lamps must be fitted to the vehicle.
The rear fog lamps must only emit a red light.
The rear fog lamp(s) must only illuminate when dipped beam, main beam or front fog lamps are lit (see alternatives in Notes 3 & 4)
Rear fog lamps must be positioned correctly to meet the positional requirements of Table 1 in Section 28 of the IVA N1 Inspection Manual.
Rear fog lamps must be positioned correctly to meet the angles of visibility requirements of Table 1 in Section 28 of the IVA N1 Inspection Manual.
Rear fog lamps must be fitted with an operational “tell-tale” lamp (non-flashing) visible from the driving position.
Either the switch or tell tale must clearly indicate that operation relates to the Rear Fog lights.
The rear fog lamps must not be operated by a brake control.
The rear fog lamps must be fitted so that the reflector is facing squarely to the rear.
An optional rear fog lamp must form a matched pair with the obligatory lamp.
An optional rear fog lamp must only operate with the obligatory rear fog lamp.
All rear fog lamps must display an “e” or “E” mark with a “B” or “F”.
The reversing lamps must be operational.
The correct number of reversing lamps must be fitted to the vehicle.
They must emit white light and be positioned as per Table 1.
The reversing lamps must be positioned to face the rear.
The reversing lamps must operate by selection of reverse gear or be fitted with a telltale warning device.
Where two reversing lamps are fitted they must be fitted symmetrically and be a matched pair.
Parking lamps are not permitted on vehicles that exceed 6metres in length, or 2metres in width.
Parking lamps must be operational.
The correct number of parking lamps must be fitted to the vehicle.
Parking lamps must only emit red light to the rear / white light to the front.
Parking lamps must be positioned to meet the positional requirements.
Parking lamps must be positioned to meet the angles of visibility requirements.
The switch must allow the parking lamp(s) on the same side of the vehicle to be lit independently of any other lamps.
A device which automatically deactivates the parking lamps as a function of time is prohibited.
A closed circuit tell-tail for the parking lamps is optional. However, if a tell tail is fitted it must not be possible to confuse it with the tell-tale for the front and rear position lamps.
Each seat requiring a belt must be fitted with a seat belt of the appropriate type.

Each seat belt must bear the appropriate approval marks or have the equivalent characteristics to that of a belt approved for the same category of vehicle to ensure the belt meets the required approval standards.
Each seat belt must be attached by an appropriate fixing and be securely fitted.
There must be no damage to the seat belt structure that would affect its strength.
The seat belt lock mechanism must securely lock the belt.
The seat belt lock mechanism must be able to be released easily, both in normal use and when the belt is under load.
With the seat belt fastened and the seat unoccupied, retractor mechanisms must take up any excess webbing.
A retractor mechanism must be correctly positioned to ensure the correct operation of the belt.
The seat belt must sit correctly across the wearers torso so as to provide effective restraint in the event of a frontal impact.
There must not be any sharp edges / objects in the seat belt area likely to cause damage to the belt.
The seat belt must be able to be stored so it is always readily accessible to use.
Where an airbag is fitted in front of a passenger position, a warning label for the airbag must be permanently fixed to the vehicle.
The warning label for the airbag must be visible in front of a person about to install a rearward facing child restraint.
The warning label for the airbag must be visible when the door is closed otherwise a permanent reference elsewhere that is visible at all times is required.
A harness or three point belt “effective upper anchorage” location must be at least 450mm above the reference point.
A lap/diagonal belt “effective upper anchorage” location must be at least 140mm from the longitudinal centre line of the seat.
The lower anchorages of the seat belts must be at least 350mm apart.
The lower anchorages of seat belts on side ward facing seats must be at least 350mm apart but no further apart than 500mm.
The driver must have a clear and un-obscured view of the road ahead and to 90° each side of straight ahead (see Note 1).
Identification of Controls, Tell-tales and Indicators must be clear so not to cause confusion.
Identification of Controls, Tell-tales and Indicators must be on or as close to the controls, tell-tales and indicators as possible as not to cause confusion.
Identification of Controls, Tell-tales and Indicators must stand out clearly from the background.
Any Information Display Device fitted must be able to display simultaneously the warning symbols for Brake, Main beam and Direction Indicator where this function is not provided elsewhere.
Any Information Display Device fitted must provide the relevant information regarding tell – tales and indicators whenever the situation that causes them to operate arises.
Any Information Display Device fitted must repeat automatically in sequence or indicate in such a manner that it is visible to and identifiable to the driver when two or more messages are given.
The vehicle must be fitted with a system capable of defrosting / demisting the windscreen.
A system using warm air to clear the screen must employ fan assistance and ducting to direct the air onto the screen, to ensure effective operation under cold weather conditions.
An electrically heated screen must provide adequate heat and distribution to ensure effective operation.
The vehicle must be fitted with a windscreen washer and wiper system to give the driver an adequate view of the road.
All front wipers must continue to move automatically over the swept area of the windscreen.
All front wipers must have at least two sweep frequencies one of which must be of at least 45 cycles/min.
Additional Sweep frequencies must be of not less than 10 and not more than 55 cycles/minute.
The difference between the highest and at least one of the lower sweep frequencies must be at least 15 cycles/minute.
All front wipers must return automatically to a position of rest which is at or beyond the outer edge of the swept area, or to a vertical position in the centre of the windscreen.
All front wipers must be capable of being lifted from the windscreen to allow for cleaning of the windscreen.
The windscreen washer system must provide enough liquid to adequately clear the windscreen in conjunction with the wipers.
The windscreen washer system must have a reservoir capacity of at least 1 litre.
The windscreen washer system must be able to withstand the load applied when the nozzles are blocked and the system is operated for 3 – 5 seconds.
Heating Systems must present no obvious fire risk (e.g. flammable parts of the vehicle near to a source of heat or a likelihood of users placing objects liable to catch fire on a very hot surface).
Heating Systems must present no obvious injury risk (e.g. likelihood of users touching a very hot surface or hot water pipes).
Heating Systems must have air intakes positioned so that there is no likelihood of polluted air being able to enter the passenger compartment, this does not include pollution from external sources.
The vehicle must be accompanied by satisfactory evidence of compliance with the required standards for "Heating Systems".
A liquid fuelled or gaseous fuelled combustion heater must be fitted in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions,
There must be no obvious fire risk associated with the heating system.
It must be positioned so that it is not likely to cause injury.

Permanent warning labels/pictograms instructing that the LPG heater shall not be in operation and that the valve of the portable LPG cylinder shall be closed when the vehicle is in motion.shall be attached. (See note 2) :
a. on the compartment where portable LPG cylinders are stored 
and
b. in close proximity to the control device for the heating system,
The vehicle as presented must be accompanied by satisfactory evidence of compliance with the required standard for “Fuel Consumption/CO2”.
Windscreens, windows and side-screens where fitted must be securely attached to the vehicle.
Windscreens, windows, internal glazed panels and side-screens where fitted must be suitable for its use.
Windscreens must be “Safety Glazing” made from glass and display the relevant markings.
Vehicles having a maximum design speed greater than 40 km/h (25 mph) may not be fitted with a toughened windscreen.
All other windows (including sunroofs and removable glass panels) and side-screens must be “Safety Glazing” (which may be made from glass, or from plastic) and display the relevant markings.
Windscreens and windows wholly or partly on either side of the drivers seat must allow a visual transmission of at least 70%, or 60% in the case of an armoured vehicle.
Driver forward vision must not be distorted by the glazing material.
Each tyre must bear an ‘E‘ or ‘e’, DOT or JIS approval mark.

Each tyre must be manufactured so that it displays permanently the following service information:
a. nominal size
b. construction type (e.g. radial, cross ply or bias belt)

Each tyre must be manufactured so that it displays permanently the following service information markings:
a. load capacity
b. speed capability, or
c. is accompanied by documentation that provides this information.

All tyres on the same axle must have the same structure (e.g. bias-belted, crossply or radial)
a. nominal size
b. aspect ratio
Tyres must be of the correct structure, taking account of their position on the vehicle and the vehicle axle configuration.
Each tyre must be of the correct nominal size for the wheel to which it is fitted.
Each tyre must have the adequate speed capability (speed rating) for the maximum design speed of the vehicle.

Each tyre must have the adequate load capacity for the axle to which it is fitted (see Annex 2 and 3 of Section 46 of the IVA N1 Inspection Manual) at the manufacturers stated maximum permitted axle weight (as indicated by documentary evidence or manufacturers plate) or where this is not available at the at the calculated maximum permitted axle weight. (for calculated axle weight see section 44 of the IVA N1 Inspection Manual). Note where both are available the higher value will be used.
Tyres must be fitted in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions as indicated on the side wall of the tyre.
The load capacity of the temporary-use spare unit must be at least equal to one half of the highest of the maximum axle loads of the vehicle.
For temporary-use spare a 80 km/h or 50mph maximum speed warning symbol / reference must be permanently displayed on the outer face of the wheel in a prominent position.
The grooves of the tread pattern must be, at least 1.6mm throughout a continuous band comprising of the centre ¾ of the breadth of tread around the outer circumference of the tyre.
The vehicle must not exceed the maximum length of 12 metres.
The vehicle must not exceed the maximum width of 2.55 metres.
Where declared the vehicle must be accompanied by satisfactory evidence of the maximum design weights, which have been assigned to the vehicle by the manufacturer.
The sum of the permitted axle weights must be equal to or greater than the maximum gross vehicle weight.
The maximum design gross weight must be equal to or greater than the calculated weights.
The maximum design front axle weight must be equal to or greater than the calculated weight.
The maximum design rear axle weight must be equal to or greater than the calculated weight.

When a vehicle is loaded to its maximum permitted gross weight and its rear axle is loaded to its maximum permitted weight, the front axle weight must not be less than 30% of the maximum gross vehicle weight.
Where an original axle design weight appears to have been exceeded evidence to increase the weights must be provided.
A vehicle which is capable of towing must have a technically permissible towing mass which conforms with the information below:

Where a vehicle is capable of towing a trailer fitted with a service braking system, the technically permissible maximum towable mass of the vehicle must not exceed either of: 
• the technically permissible mass of the towing vehicle, (OR,  for off- road vehicles 1.5 times that mass 
• 3500Kg

If a vehicle is fitted with one or more loadable axles, satisfactory evidence must be provided stating that under all driving conditions, the axle will lower to the ground automatically when the front axle or the nearest axle of a group of axles is loaded.

The motor vehicle must be able to manoeuvre for a complete circular trajectory of 360 degrees within the defined area shown in Figure 1 in Section 48 of the IVA N1 Inspection Manual (with the exception of the protruding parts prescribed for the vehicle width shown in Annex 1 of that Section)

Any part of the vehicle must not move outside of the vertical plane of the defined area shown in Figure 1 in Section 48 of the IVA N1 Inspection Manual, by more than 0.8 metres, or for vehicles with retractable axles in the lifted position, or loadable axles in the un-laden condition, the figure of 0,80 m is replaced by 1,00 m. (For vehicles with an axle-lift device this requirement also applies with the axle(s) in the lifted position )

A mascot, emblem or other ornamental object must retract or detach when a reasonable force is applied, and leave a base or mounting free from sharp edges that does not protrude from the surface by more than 10mm.
All ‘hard’ parts contactable with a 100mm sphere, which form an external surface or protrude 5mm or more from the external surface must have a radius of curvature of at least 2.5mm.
Protrusions less than 5mm but more than 1.5mm contactable with a 100mm sphere must have blunted edges.
Wheel arches must be ‘turned inwards’, or have a radius of curvature of at least 2.5mm.
Grills, gaps, slots, grooves, channels, recesses and holes that have a width of 10mm or less as determined by the contact points of a 100mm sphere must be blunted.

Grills, gaps, slots, grooves, channels, recesses and holes which have a width of more than 10mm, and up to 25mm determined by the contact points of a 100mm sphere must have a radius of curvature of at least 0.5mm.

Grills, gaps, slots, grooves, channels, recesses and holes which have a width of more than 25mm, and up to 40mm determined by the contact points of a 100mm sphere must have a radius of curvature of at least 1mm.
Grills, gaps, slots, grooves, channels, recesses and holes which have a width of more than 40mm determined by the contact points of a 100mm sphere must have a radius of curvature of at least 2.5mm.
Where contactable with the 100mm sphere sheet metal edges must be folded back on themselves (180 degrees).
Where contactable with the 100mm sphere a glass/fibre reinforced plastic panel edge must have a radius of curvature of at least 1.5mm.
Wiper blades and their support arms must be at least blunted.
Wheel nuts, hub caps and protective devices must not exhibit any fin-shaped projections.

Protective device(s) with a radius of curvature of at least 5mm must be fitted to wheel securing bolts, nuts or hubs if they protrude beyond the upper half of the tyre surface. The protective devices which cover wheel nuts and hubs may project beyond the body plan by no more than 30 mm.
The upper half of a wheel must not protrude beyond the cab body plan form (disregarding tyres).
The edges on lateral air and rain deflectors and window anti-smear air deflectors, capable of being directed outwards must have a radius of curvature of not less than 1 mm.
Aerial shafts must be blunted and fitted with a’ fixed end capping’ with a radius of curvature of at least 2.5mm.
The ends of front protective devices (bumpers) must be turned inwards towards the external surface of the body.

The components of bumpers projecting 5mm or more must be so designed that all rigid surfaces facing outwards have a radius of curvature of not less than 5 mm. The edges of devices projecting less than 5 mm must be blunted.

Equipment such as towing hitches and winches must not protrude beyond the foremost surface of the bumper. However, winches may protrude beyond the foremost surface of the bumper provided they are covered when not in use by a suitable protective covering having a radius of curvature of not less than 2.5 mm.
Push buttons must not protrude more than 30mm.
Handles (other than grab handles), hinges, and fuel tank filler caps must not protrude more than 50mm.
Grab handles and bonnet fasteners must not project more than 70mm.

Headlight visors and rims must not project more than 30mm beyond the lens surface (measured horizontally from the point of contact of a 100mm sphere touching lens and visor/rim or the adjacent bodywork and the visor/rim if the lamp is recessed).
Handles that rotate or pivot outwards must be enclosed in a protective surround or be recessed, unless they cannot in any circumstance project beyond the extreme outer edge of the cab.
Handles that rotate parallel to the plane of the panel must be turned inwards towards the plane of the panel.
The open end of any handle that rotates parallel to the plane of the panel and protrudes beyond the extreme outer edge of the cab must face rearwards.

Any handle that does not protrude beyond the extreme outer edge of the cab must have:
a. The open end facing rearwards, or

Any handle that does not protrude beyond the extreme outer edge of the cab must have:
b. the open end shielded to the front by a protective surround

Any handle that does not protrude beyond the extreme outer edge of the cab must have:
c. the open end recessed into the bodywork

Any handle that does not protrude beyond the extreme outer edge of the cab must have:
d. a gap measuring a maximum of 2mm between the open end of the handle and the vehicle body.

Handles that pivot outwards must have the open end facing rearwards or downwards, unless they have an independent return mechanism which in event of failure will not allow the handle to project more than 15mm.

An exhaust tailpipe must not project beyond the floor line or the vertical projection of the intersection of the reference plane with the external surface of the vehicle lying directly above it by more than 10mm, unless it terminates in a radius of curvature of at least 2.5mm.
The coupling devices must be of an approved type and have the correct markings.
The coupling frame must bear an ‘e’ or ‘E’ mark to ensure the construction of the device meets the appropriate approval criteria.
The coupling device(s) must be securely mounted to the vehicle.
The vehicle structure, to which the coupling is attached and any fixings used, must be of sufficient strength relevant to the coupling fitted
The coupling ball and / or towing bracket must be installed to the correct height. (see Note 1)
If a coupling device is fitted then the vehicle must be provided with a Gross Train Weight, which must satisfy the requirements of Section 44.
The vehicle as presented must be accompanied by satisfactory evidence of compliance with the required standard for “Side Impact”.
The Frontal Protection System must display a genuine permanently attached ‘e’ mark that would be applied at the time of manufacture.
The vehicle as presented must be accompanied by satisfactory documentary evidence of compliance with the required standard for electric/hybrid vehicles (see Note 1).
The vehicle as presented must be accompanied by satisfactory documentary evidence of compliance with the required standard for electric/hybrid vehicles.

All high voltage cable terminations must be suitably protected, these protections (solid insulator, barrier, enclosure, etc.) shall not be able to be opened, disassembled or removed without the use of tools            (see Note 2).
Any enclosure carrying high voltage shall be clearly marked with an indelible label affixed in a visible location.
All visible high voltage cables must be orange in colour.

All metal enclosures with internal high voltage must have an earth path for protection against electrical shock (this may be a separate bonding or the mounting arrangement where it does not isolate the enclosure)
All aspects of the design and construction of the vehicle must be such that no Immediate danger is caused or likely to be caused to any person in the vehicle or to other road users.
All aperture covers (other than doors), including tailgates, boot and bonnet lids must be capable of being latched in the fully closed position.
When driven, the safe control of the vehicle must not be impaired or likely to be impaired, due to a design or construction feature of characteristic.
The vehicle structure and all components including their attachment must be suitable and of adequate strength.

A transmission/braking component which rotates during vehicle operation, electrical component, steering or suspension component, wheel or tyre must not foul on another component, or be likely to foul under normal operating conditions.
Fuel and electrical components must not be subject to either a corrosive environment or be exposed to heat sources likely to cause premature failure.
All steering, suspension, brake and fuel system components must not be leaking.
All electrical cables/wires must be free from chaffing and secured at intervals of at least every 300mm unless contained in a secure hollow component.
All electrical components must be secure, be of adequate capacity, and be insulated as required as to prevent short circuiting during operation.
The vehicle as presented must be accompanied by satisfactory evidence of compliance with the required standard for ”Noise” (See note 1)
The exhaust system must be fitted with a silencer.
The exhaust system must be securely mounted.
Exhaust system components must be secure.
The exhaust outlet must be positioned so that exhaust gases cannot damage other components of the vehicle, or cause a hazard to people in the vehicle.
There must be no leaks from the exhaust system (See note 2)

Where an air braking system has been modified, any high pressure brake exhaust outlet must be fitted with a silencer, or satisfactory evidence supplied to show compliance with the required standard.
(See note 3)
The measured sound level must not exceed 99dbA (See notes 4 & 5)
An M2 or M3 vehicle as presented must be accompanied by satisfactory evidence of compliance with the required standard for either “Light duty emissions” or Heavy duty “Emissions”. (See Table 1)
The exhaust must not emit excessive smoke or vapour of any colour to an extent likely to obscure the vision of other road users
The vehicle as presented must be accompanied by satisfactory documentary evidence with the required standard for “Fuel Tanks” (see note 1)
The fuel tank must not be located in, or form part of an occupant compartment or other compartment integral with it.
There must not be an aperture in a partition separating the occupant compartment from the fuel tank that would allow fuel to flow freely into the occupant compartment during normal conditions of use.
The fuel filler opening must not be located in the occupant, luggage or engine compartment.
The fuel tank must be securely attached to the vehicle.
The fuel tank must be positioned so it is protected from damage from protruding parts or sharp edges in the event of a front or rear impact.
The fuel tank must be mounted so as not to be fouled by moving parts of the vehicle, or likely to be subject to abrasion by adjacent parts.
The tank must not be mounted in a position that would allow any fuel leaking from the tank or pipe work into the occupant compartment.
Any fuel filler neck or vent must not allow spilt fuel to be able to fall onto the exhaust system.
An approved vent device must be fitted to the fuel tank.
An approved fuel filler cap must positively locate to the filler neck and incorporate an adequate sealing arrangement so that a fuel leak is not possible. See note 2
All metal fuel tanks must have an earth path to prevent the build up of static electricity. (this may be a separate bonding or the mounting arrangement where it does not isolate the tank)

The fuel filler cap must either be tethered to the vehicle or be of a lockable type where the key can only be removed when the cap is locked or an automatically opening and closing, non-removable fuel filler cap
Where required the vehicle as presented must be accompanied by satisfactory evidence of compliance regarding the protective system (See notes 1 & 2)
The rear structure must be of sufficient strength to prevent under-run by a smaller vehicle. (See note 3)
Any separate device must be fitted as close to the rear of the vehicle as possible.
When the vehicle is unladen the lower edge of the device (separate device or body structure) must at no point be more than 550 mm above the ground.
The width of any separate device must at no point exceed the width of the rear axle measured at the outermost points of the wheels, (excluding the bulging of the tyres close to the ground).
The width of any device (separate device or body structure) must not be less than that of the widest rear axle by more than 100 mm on either side.
All vehicles must comply with one of the “options” listed in table 1.
The space must permit the mounting of a plate in a position as close to vertical as possible taking into account the shape of the bodywork.
An external body surface or a purpose-designed mounting system securely attached to the vehicle must be provided to hold the plate in a fixed position. (see note1)
The whole of the shaded portion of the “IVA Test plate must be capable of being easily seen from every point along the test line.
The vehicle as presented must be accompanied by satisfactory evidence of compliance with the required standard for “Steering Effort”.
The steering system must operate smoothly from lock to lock and without undue stiffness.
The vehicle must be fitted with a horn (see note 1)
The horn must be securely attached to the vehicle.
When operated the horn must emit a continuous uniform sound (See note 2)
The horn as installed, must give an equivalent level of warning to other road users as that of an equivalent M2/M3 EC Type Approved vehicle. (See note 2).
The vehicle must have all obligatory mirrors fitted (see Note 5 and Table 1)
All mirrors must be securely attached to the vehicle (see note 1)
All obligatory mirrors must bear an acceptable European approval mark (‘E’ or ‘e’).
All obligatory mirrors must bear the appropriate class type (see table 1)
All mirrors must be adjustable
All obligatory mirrors must meet the field of view requirements (see note 2 and Figure 1 )
If a class V or VI mirror is mounted then regardless of their position after adjustment, no part of these mirrors or their holders must be less than 2 m from the ground.(See note 3)
Exterior mirrors shall be visible through the side windows or through the portion of the windscreen that is swept by the windscreen wiper. (See note 4)
The vehicle as presented must be accompanied by satisfactory evidence of compliance with the required standard for “Braking”.
The vehicle as presented must be accompanied by satisfactory evidence of compliance with the required standard for “EMC”.
Where any additional equipment has been installed, a declaration supplied by the Manufacturer / applicant, confirming compliance of the additional items must be presented (see note 1).
Where an anti theft device incorporates a mechanical part that acts upon a system used to control the vehicle; It must Deactivate before the engine can be started.
Where an anti theft device incorporates a mechanical part that acts upon a system used to control the vehicle; It must be deactivated while the engine is running.

Where an anti theft device incorporates a mechanical part that acts upon a system used to control the vehicle; It must have a actuation which is a distinct and separate function from that of stopping the engine.
Where an anti theft device incorporates a mechanical part that acts upon a system used to control the vehicle; It must not operate on any part of the braking system.
If fitted to the Vehicle, an Immobiliser  must be accompanied by evidence of compliance  (see note 1)
If fitted to the Vehicle, an Alarm must be accompanied by evidence of compliance (see note 1)
If fitted to the Vehicle, an Panic Alarm must be accompanied by evidence of compliance (see notes 1 & 2)

All seats must be adequate in strength and securely mounted to a load bearing part of the structure, or have adequate support to spread the load of the seat mounting if attached to a non-metallic floor pan separate from the chassis. (see notes 1, 2, and 3)
Where seats incorporate seat belt anchorages the seat must be approved to at least the category of vehicle to which they are fitted
All seat mountings must be of adequate strength to support the loads likely to be imposed (see notes 1 and 3).
Each moveable seat, seat back adjustment and seat displacement system must incorporate an automatic locking system which operates in all positions provided for normal use (see Note 1 & 4).
All seats which can be tipped forward or have fold-down backs must lock automatically in the normal (see Note 1 & 4).

Where seats are intended for use only when the vehicle is not being driven on public roads, the seats must be accompanied by a pictogram or sign clearly indicating that the seat is not to be used whilst the vehicle is in motion

For seating positions where the seat belt anchorages are not mounted on the seat, but are fixed directly to the floor or other body structure, the vehicle as presented must be accompanied by satisfactory evidence of compliance with the required standard for seat belt anchorages  (See note 5)
Seats with integral seat belts fitted must have anchorages that comply with section 19 (Seat Belt Anchorages).
A system of padded head restraint must be fitted on every outboard front seat.
For outboard front seats the height of the top of the head restraint above the R point must be at least 700mm (see note 6, 7 and annex 1)
The head restraint must be at least 85 mm wide each side of the vertical centre line of the seat and at least 100mm high.
The head restraint must be securely attached to the seat. (see note 8)
The head restraint must not have any roughness or sharp edges likely to increase the risk of severity of injury. (see note 8)
The padding of the head restraint must be sufficient so as to prevent any contact by a head with any of the internal hard parts of the head restraint. (see note 8)
The vehicle must be fitted with an Analogue Tachograph or a Speedometer capable of accurately indicating the speed of the vehicle (See note 1 & 2)
The tachograph or speedometer must be capable of being read at all times of the day or night
Imperial (mph) and metric (km/h) units must be permanently marked on the dial face (see Note 3).
The “rest” position for the needle must lie either on or below the first marked increment. (See note 4)

If an analogue tachograph is not fitted then a speedometer must be fitted and be capable of indicating the vehicle speed in miles per hour (mph) and kilometres per hour (Km/h) at uniform intervals not exceeding 20mph for all speeds up to the maximum design speed of the vehicle. (See note 5)
The vehicle must have a reverse gear which can be selected from the driving position and operates (See note 6)
The vehicle must be fitted with a manufacturer’s plate, in a conspicuous and readily accessible position.
A manufacturer’s plate must be fitted for each stage of a multistage build.
The manufacturer’s plate(s) must be made of a durable material
All plate(s) must be indelibly marked with the Vehicle Identification Number (VIN) which matches the number marked into the vehicle structure. (see note 1)
The manufacturer’s plate(s) must be securely attached to a part of the vehicle that will not be replaced through normal use. (see note 2)
The manufacturer’s plate(s) must show the required information, in the correct order inside a clearly marked rectangle. See Annex 1
The Vehicle Identification number on the manufacturer’s plate must be marked in characters at least 4mm high
The characters on the manufacturer’s plate (with the exception of the Vehicle Identification Number) must be at least 2mm high.
The VIN must be marked on the chassis, frame or other similar structure on the right hand side of the vehicle. ( viewed from the rear )
The VIN must be placed in a clearly visible and accessible position by a method such as hammering or stamping so that it cannot be obliterated or deteriorate
The VIN number must consist of 17 digits with the information shown in a single line (see notes 3 & 4)
Capital letters and numerals must be used for the VIN
There must not be any gaps between the characters for the VIN or unique vehicle identifier number shown on the manufacturer’s plate or stamped into the vehicle. (see note 4)
The characters used for the VIN number stamped into the chassis, frame or other similar structure must be at least 7mm high
Use of the letter I, the letter O, the letter Q, dashes, asterisks and other special signs are not permitted
Where the VIN has been changed in agreement with the Approval Authority, evidence of the agreement with the approval authority must be provided
Where the VIN has been changed in agreement with the Approval Authority, the original complete vehicle identification number of the base vehicle must be present on the chassis
Where the VIN has been changed in agreement with the Approval Authority, the complete new VIN must be stamped on the chassis as near as possible to the original VIN
Where the VIN has been changed in agreement with the Approval Authority, the last eight characters of the new VIN must be identical to the last eight characters of the base vehicle VIN

For vehicles with seat belts fitted to secure passengers in forward or rearward facing seats, the vehicle as presented must be accompanied by satisfactory evidence of compliance with the required standard for “Seat belt anchorages”.   (see notes 1 & 2)

For vehicles with seat belts fitted to secure passengers in Side Facing Seats, the belt anchorage points, including the seat anchorage for belts mounted directly to a seat, must be securely attached to the vehicle structure, or other obvious suitable load bearing parts of the vehicle (see Notes 3 & 4).

The vehicle must be fitted with lamps or retro reflective material only capable of showing a white light to the front except for:

• an amber light from a direction indicator
• a yellow light from a front fog lamp
• an amber light from a side marker light
• emergency vehicles only, a blue light from a warning lamp or beacon. 
• light from destination board

The vehicle must be fitted with lamps or retro reflective material only capable of showing a red light to the rear except for:

• an amber light from a direction indicator
• a white light from a work lamp, reversing lamp, interior lamp, or a registration plate lamp
• a yellow light from a rear registration plate
• an amber light from a side marker light
• emergency vehicles only, a blue light from a warning lamp or beacon. 
• light from destination board
The operation of any lamp must not effect any other lamp or be affected by the operation of any other lamp, unless specifically designed to do so

All lamps and reflectors must be securely fitted to the vehicle and not move by swivelling, deflecting, or otherwise while the vehicle is in motion, except for:
• any lamp or reflector which by design can be deflected to the side with the movement of the front wheel or wheels of the vehicle when turned for the purpose of steering the vehicle
• a headlamp for adjustment or dipping of the beam
• a headlamp which can be retracted or concealed
• a work lamp, used to illuminate a working area or the scene of an accident, breakdown or road works in the vicinity of the vehicle to which it is fitted.
All obligatory and optional lamps, reflectors and rear markers must be fitted to their correct orientation

When every door or other movable part is in the fixed open position (any position in which the component will remain, with or without a fixed stay) the
• front and rear position lamps
• front and rear indicators
• rear retro reflectors
must fulfil one of the following conditions: 
a. half (50%) of the apparent surface of the lamp / reflector is visible from directly in front of / behind (as appropriate) the vehicle, or
b. additional fully visible lamp (s) / reflector (s) satisfying all requirements for the above lamps are activated / visible, or
c. a notice in the vehicle must inform the user that in certain positions of the movable components, other road users should be warned of the presence of the vehicle on the road (e.g. by laying out a warning triangle).(see note 1)
All reflectors must be ‘e’ or ‘E’ marked and where applicable, bear the appropriate identity marking as listed in Table 1
The correct number must be fitted to the vehicle (Table 1)
The correct colour must be fitted to the vehicle (Table 1)
The retro reflectors must be positioned to meet positional requirements. Note 1 and Table 1
The retro reflectors must be positioned to meet the angles of visibility requirements. Note 1 and table 1
They must be of the correct shape (Table 1)
Rear reflectors must face predominately to the rear

sectionDescription: End Outline, Position (Side), Stop, Side Marker & Daytime Running Lights

requiredStandards.requiredStandard: They must be of the correct shape (Table 1)
The front and rear position lamps, end outline marker lamps and side marker lamps, (if fitted) must be switched on and off by the operation of one switch. See Note 1
The correct number of front and rear position lamps must be fitted to the vehicle. Table 1
The front and rear position lamps must be operational.
The front and rear position lamps must only emit white light to the front / red light to the rear.
The front and rear position lamps must be positioned to meet the positional requirements. (Note 2 Table 1)
The front and rear position lamps must be positioned to meet the angles of visibility requirements. (Note 2 Table 1)
The correct number of stop lamps must be fitted to the vehicle. (Table 1)
All stop lamps must be operational.
The stop lamps must only emit red light.
The stop lamps must only illuminate when the the service brake is applied, and must extinguish when the service brake is released.
The stop  lights must be so positioned so as to meet the positional requirements of Table 1, Note 2
The stop  lights must be so positioned so as to meet the angles of visibility requirements of Table 1, Note 2
The correct number of side marker lamps must be fitted to the vehicle. (in accordance to the positional requirements) Note 3
The side marker lights must be operational.
The side marker lights must emit an amber light. (red is acceptable if within 1 metre of the rear)
The side marker lights must be positioned to meet the positional requirements of Table 1
The side marker lights must be positioned to meet the angles of visibility requirements of Table 1
The correct number of end outline marker lamps must be fitted to the vehicle. Table 1 Note 4 & 5
The end outline marker lamps must be operational.
The end outline marker lamps must only emit red light to the rear / white light to the front.
The end outline marker lamps must be a minimum of 200mm from any position lamp.
The end outline marker lamps must be positioned to meet the positional requirements of Table 1, Note 1
The end outline marker lamps must be positioned to meet the angles of visibility requirements of Table 1, Note 1
The correct number of daytime running lamps must be fitted to the vehicle. Table 1
Daytime running lamps must be operational.
The daytime running lamps must only emit white light to the front.
The daytime running lamps must be positioned to meet the positional requirements of Table 1
The daytime running lamps must be positioned to meet the angles of visibility requirements of Table 1
They must extinguish automatically when headlamps are operated. (see note 6)
All direction indicator lamps must be ‘e’ or ‘E’ marked and where applicable, bear the appropriate identity marking as listed in Table
The direction indicator lamps must be operational.
The correct number of direction indicator lamps must be fitted to the vehicle. Table 1
The indicators must flash at a rate of between 60 and 120 times a minute. (with all mandatory indicators working, and with the engine running if initially below the requirement)
There must be an audible or visual tell tale fitted to indicate the operation of any indicators.
All direction indicator lamps must emit amber light.
The direction indicator lamps must be positioned to meet the positional requirements of Table 1, Note 1
The direction indicator lamps must be positioned to meet the angles of visibility requirements of Table 1, Note 1
The hazard warning lamps must operate with the ignition switched on and off.
The hazard warning device must operate all of the direction indicators simultaneously.
The hazard warning device must have a telltale warning light fitted which is circuit specific.
All rear registration plate lamps must be ‘e’ or ‘E’ marked.
The rear registration plate lamps must be operational.
The rear registration plate lamps must be able to be switched on and off with the front and rear position lights by operating one switch.
The rear registration plate lamps must only emit white light.
The rear registration plate lamps must be positioned to sufficiently illuminate the rear registration plate. Note 1
All lamps must be ‘e’ or ‘E’ marked and where applicable, bear the appropriate identity marking as listed in table 1
They must be operational
All obligatory and optional headlamps must be fitted as “matched pairs”.
All headlamps must emit a white light.
When on dip or main beam, headlamps must emit sufficient light to be able to illuminate the road in front of the vehicle.
The correct number of headlamps must be fitted to the vehicle. Table 1
Dipped beam headlamps must be positioned to meet the requirements of Table 1
There must be a tell-tale when the headlamps are on main beam note 1

Must be accompanied by evidence of compliance with the technical requirements if not compliant with the following:
• is "E" or "e" marked
• dipped beam remains on when main beam is on (gas discharge only)
• is fitted with a wash system
• is fitted with an automatic headlamp self levelling system or self levelling suspension
The dipped beam image ‘kick-up’ must not be to the offside.
For headlamps with centres not more than 850mm from the ground, the dipped beam image horizontal cut-off must be between the horizontal 0.5% and 2% lines, i.e. the red tolerance band.
For headlamps with centres more than 850mm from the ground, the dipped beam image horizontal cutoff must be between the horizontal 1.25% and 2.75% lines, i.e. the blue tolerance band.
The dipped beam image ‘break point’ must not be to the right of the 0% vertical line, or to the left of the vertical 2% line.

The vehicle must be marked with a clearly legible and indelible marking showing the setting recommended by the manufacturer for the downward inclination of the horizontal part of the cut-off of the beam pattern of the dipped-beam headlamps, that setting shall be a single figure-  ( see note 3 )
a. between 1 and 1.5 per cent if the height of the centre of the headlamp is not more than 850 mm above the ground, and
b. between 1 and 2 per cent if the height of the centre of the headlamp is more than 850 mm above the ground.
