The seat belt anchorage must be correctly located so to ensure the belt will sit correctly on the wearer.
The anchorage and surrounding structure must be of adequate strength to withstand the load likely to be imposed by the torso in the event of a vehicle frontal impact. ( annex 1)

Those seats which are not intended for use when the vehicle is driven on a public road must be accompanied with a pictogram or sign clearly indicating that the seat is not to be used whilst the vehicle is in motion. (See note 4).

The vehicle must be fitted with lamps or retro reflective material only capable of showing a white light to the front except for:

• an amber light from a direction indicator
• a yellow light from a front fog lamp
• an amber light from a side marker light
• emergency vehicles only, a blue light from a warning lamp or beacon. 
• an amber light from a hazard beacon / warning lamp
• a yellow light from a conspicuity marking material
• a red light from a rearmost side marker or rear position lamp

The vehicle must be fitted with lamps or retro reflective material only capable of showing a red light to the rear except for:

• an amber light from a direction indicator 
• a white light from a work lamp, reversing lamp, interior lamp, or a registration plate lamp
• a yellow light from a rear registration plate
• an amber light from a side marker light
• emergency vehicles only, a blue light from a warning lamp or beacon. 
• an amber light from a hazard beacon / warning lamp
• a yellow light from a conspicuity marking material
.
The operation of any lamp must not affect any other lamp or be affected by the operation of any other lamp, unless specifically designed to do so

All lamps, reflectors and rear markers must be securely fitted to the vehicle and not move by swivelling, deflecting or otherwise while the vehicle is in motion, except for:
• any lamp or reflector which by design can be deflected to the side with the movement of the front wheel or wheels of the vehicle when turned for the purpose of steering the vehicle
• a headlamp for adjustment or dipping of the beam
• a headlamp which can be retracted or concealed
• a work lamp, used to illuminate a working area or the scene of an accident, breakdown or road works in the vicinity of the vehicle to which it is fitted.
All obligatory and optional lamps, reflectors and rear markers must be fitted to their correct orientation
a. half (50%) of the apparent surface of the lamp / reflector is visible from directly in front of / behind (as appropriate) the vehicle
b. additional fully visible lamp (s) / reflector (s) satisfying all requirements for the above lamps / reflectors are activated / visible

c. a notice in the vehicle must inform the user that in certain positions of the movable components, other road users should be warned of the presence of the vehicle on the road (e.g. by laying out a warning triangle). (see Note 1)
All reflectors must be ‘e’ or ‘E’ marked, and where applicable, bear the appropriate identity marking as listed in Table 1
The correct number of retro reflectors must be fitted to the vehicle. (Table 1 )
The correct colour of retro reflectors must be fitted to the vehicle. (Table 1 )
The retro reflectors must be positioned to meet positional requirements of Table 1. (see Note 1)
The retro reflectors must be positioned to meet the angles of visibility requirements. of Table 1 (see Note 1)
The retro reflectors must be of the correct shape. (Table 1)
Rear reflectors must face predominately to the rear.
Full or part conspicuity markings must be fitted to vehicles more than 750kg. DGW, 6.0m long and 2.1m wide. (See Note 2)
All conspicuity marking material must be of an approved type. see note 3)
There must be at least one visable approval mark on any element of a retro-reflective marking material fitted to each face of the vehicle (o/s, n/s & rear).
The maximum gap between adjacent elements must be no greater than 50% of the smallest adjacent element (see note 4)
The lowest edge must be between 250mm and 1500mm from the ground. (see note 5)
The minimum width of the conspicuity markings must be at least 50mm.
The maximum width of the markings must be no greater than 60mm.
Rear Conspicuity Markings must be coloured either red or yellow.
Rear Conspicuity Markings must equate to at least 70% of the overall vehicle width (see note 6 & figure 5)
Rear Conspicuity Markings must be at least 200mm away from any brake mandatory light (see figure 4 A)
Side Conspicuity markings must be coloured either white or yellow.
Side Conspicuity markings must extend within 600mm of either end of the vehicle. (see figure 2)
Side Conspicuity markings 19. must equate to at least 70% of the overall vehicle length (see Notes 7 & 12 and figure 8)
Vehicle Cabs must be fitted with line markings (see Notes 8 & 12)
Where full or partial contour markings are fitted the maximum height must be as close as is practical to the top of the body. (see figure 2) (See Note 9)
Where full or partial contour markings are fitted the vertical aspect of marking must be as close to the edge as practicable. (see figure 4 B).
Where partial contour markings are fitted each side of a Tick Marking must be at least 250mm (see note 10 & figure 3)
All Rear Markers must bear a genuine permanently attached ‘e’ mark.
A minimum of one set of obligatory markers must be fitted to the vehicle (see note 11 & Table 2 )
All Rear Markers must be positioned correctly to meet the positional requirements of Table 2
They must be of the correct type ( Table 2 )

sectionDescription: End Outline, Position (Side), Stop, Side Marker & Daytime Running Lights

requiredStandards.requiredStandard: All lamps must be ‘e’ or ‘E’ marked and where applicable, bear the appropriate identity marking as listed in table 1
The front and rear position lamps, end outline marker lamps and side marker lamps, (if fitted) must be switched on and off by the operation of one switch. See Note 1
The correct number of front and rear position lamps must be fitted to the vehicle. ( Table 1 )
The front and rear position lamps must be operational.
The front and rear position lamps must only emit white light to the front / red light to the rear.
The front and rear position lamps must be positioned to meet the positional requirements of Table 1 (see note 2)
The front and rear position lamps must be positioned to meet the angles of visibility requirements of Table 1 (see note 2)
The correct number of stop lamps must be fitted to the vehicle. (Table 1)
All stop lamps must be operational.
The stop lamps must only emit red light.
They must only illuminate when the service brake is applied, and must extinguish when the service brake is released
The stop  lights must be so positioned so as to meet the positional requirements of Table 1 (see note 2)
The stop  lights must be so positioned so as to meet the angles of visibility requirements of Table 1 (see note 2)
The correct number of side marker lamps must be fitted to the vehicle. (in accordance to the positional requirements) ( see notes (3 & 4)
The side marker lights must be operational. ( see notes (3 & 4)
The side marker lights must emit an amber light. (red is acceptable if within 1 metre of the rear) ( see notes (3 & 4)
The side marker lights must be positioned to meet the positional requirements of Table 1 ( see notes (3 & 4)
The side marker lights must be positioned to meet the angles of visibility requirements of Table 1 ( see notes (3 & 4)
The correct number of end outline marker lamps must be fitted to the vehicle.( Table 1 ) see note 5 & 6)
The end outline marker lamps must be operational.see note 5 & 6)
The end outline marker lamps must only emit red light to the rear / white light to the front.see note 5 & 6)
The end outline marker lamps must be a minimum of 200mm from any position lamp.see note 5 & 6)
The end outline marker lamps must be positioned to meet the positional requirements of Table 1 (see note 1)
The end outline marker lamps must be positioned to meet the angles of visibility requirements of Table 1 (see note 1)
The correct number of daytime running lamps must be fitted to the vehicle. (Table 1)
The daytime running lamps must be operational.
The daytime running lamps must only emit white light to the front.
The daytime running lamps must be positioned to meet the positional requirements of Table 1
The daytime running lamps must be positioned to meet the angles of visibility requirements of Table 1
The daytime running lamps must extinguish automatically when headlamps are operated. (see note 7)
All direction indicator lamps must be ‘e’ or ‘E’ marked and where applicable, bear the appropriate identity marking as listed in Table 1
The direction indicator lamps must be operational.
The correct number of direction indicator lamps must be fitted to the vehicle. (table 1)
The indicators must flash at a rate of between 60 and 120 times a minute. (with all mandatory indicators working, and with the engine running if initially below the requirement)
There must be an audible or visual tell tale fitted to indicate the operation of any indicators.
All direction indicator lamps must emit amber light.
The direction indicator lamps must be positioned to meet the positional requirements of Table 1 (see note 1)
The direction indicator lamps must be positioned to meet the angles of visibility requirements of Table 1 (see note 1)
The hazard warning lamps must operate with the ignition switched on and off.
The hazard warning device must operate all of the direction indicators simultaneously.
The hazard warning device must have a telltale warning light fitted which is circuit specific.
All rear registration plate lamps must be ‘e’ or ‘E’ marked
The rear registration plate lamps must be operational.
The rear registration plate lamps must be able to be switched on and off with the front and rear position lights by operating one switch.
The rear registration plate lamps must only emit white light.
The rear registration plate lamps must be positioned to sufficiently illuminate the rear registration plate (see Note 1).
All lamps must be ‘e’ or ‘E’ marked and where applicable, bear the appropriate identity marking as listed in Table 1
All headlamps must be operational.
All obligatory and optional headlamps must be fitted as “matched pairs”.
All headlamps must emit a white light.
When on dip or main beam, headlamps must emit sufficient light to be able to illuminate the road in front of the vehicle.
The correct number of headlamps must be fitted to the vehicle (table 1)
Dipped beam headlamps must be positioned to meet the requirements of Table 1 in Section 25 of the IVA N2 - N3 Inspection Manual.
There must be a tell-tale when on main beam (See note 1)

Gas Discharge and L.E.D Headlamps must be accompanied by evidence of compliance with the technical requirements if not compliant with the following:
• is "E" or "e" marked
• dipped beam remains on when main beam is on
• is fitted with a wash system
• is fitted with an automatic headlamp self levelling system or self levelling suspension
The dipped beam image ‘kick-up’ must not be to the offside. (see note 2)
For headlamps with centres not more than 850mm from the ground, the dipped beam image horizontal cut-off must be between the horizontal 0.5% and 2% lines, i.e. the red tolerance band. (see note 2)
For headlamps with centres more than 850mm from the ground, the dipped beam image horizontal cutoff must be between the horizontal 1.25% and 2.75% lines, i.e. the blue tolerance band. (see Note 4)
The dipped beam image ‘break point’ must not be to the right of the 0% vertical line, or to the left of the vertical 2% line. (see note 2)

The vehicle must be marked with a clearly legible and indelible marking showing the setting recommended by the manufacturer for the downward inclination of the horizontal part of the cut-off of the beam pattern of the dipped-beam headlamps, that setting shall be a single figure-  ( see note 3 )
a. between 1 and 1.5 per cent if the height of the centre of the headlamp is not more than 850 mm above the ground

The vehicle must be marked with a clearly legible and indelible marking showing the setting recommended by the manufacturer for the downward inclination of the horizontal part of the cut-off of the beam pattern of the dipped-beam headlamps, that setting shall be a single figure-  ( see note 3 )
b. between 1 and 2 per cent if the height of the centre of the headlamp is more than 850 mm above the ground.
All front fog lamps must be ‘e’ or ‘E’ marked and, where applicable, bear the appropriate identity marking as listed in Table 1
The correct number of front fog lamps must be fitted to the vehicle. Table 1
The front fog lamps must be operational.
The front fog lamps must be able to be switched on only when the position lights are on and must operate independently of the dipped and main beam headlamps. (See note 1)
The front fog lamps must only emit white or yellow light.
The front fog lamps must be positioned correctly to meet the positional requirements of Table 1
The vehicle must have a suitable towing device on the front of the vehicle to allow the attachment of a rigid towing bar.
Any towing hook or eye, mounting arrangement, bracket, or surrounding vehicle structure must be able to withstand the loads expected. (see note 1 and 2)
All rear fog lamps must be ‘e’ or ‘E’ marked and where applicable, bear the appropriate identity marking as listed in Table 1
The rear fog lamps must be operational.
The correct number must be fitted to the vehicle ( Table 1 and note 1)
The rear fog lamp(s) must only illuminate when dipped beam, main beam or front fog lamps are lit (See alternatives in note 2 & 3)
The rear fog lamps must not be affected by switching on or off any other lamps (except those above)

Can be switched off independently of any other lamp, and either:
a.  may continue to be operated until the position lamps are switched off and then must remain off until deliberately switched back on

Can be switched off independently of any other lamp, and either:
b.  a warning, at least audible, additional to the mandatory tell tale is given if the ignition is switched off or the ignition key is withdrawn and the driver's door is opened whilst the rear fog lamp switch is in the 'on' position
The rear fog lamps must only emit a red light.
The rear fog lamps must be positioned correctly to meet the positional requirements of Table 1 see note 4
The rear fog lamps must be positioned correctly to meet the angles of visibility requirements of Table 1
The rear fog lamps must be fitted with an operational “tell-tale” lamp (non-flashing) visible from the driving position.
The rear fog lamps must not be operated by a brake control.
The rear fog lamps must be fitted so that the reflector is facing squarely to the rear.
Where two rear fog lamps are fitted they must form a matched pair.
Where two rear fog lamps are fitted they must operate as a matched pair
All reversing lamps must be ‘e’ or ‘E’ marked and, where applicable, bear the appropriate identity marking as listed in Table 1
The reversing lamps must be operational.
The correct number of reversing lamps must be fitted to the vehicle. (table 1)
The reversing lamps must emit white light.
They must be positioned to face the rear and meet the positional requirements of Table 1
The reversing lamps must operate by selection of reverse gear or be fitted with a telltale warning device.

Where optional lamps are fitted, the devices must be activated and deactivated manually by a separate switch used to control the front and rear position lamps, end outline marker lamps and side marker lamps,

Where optional lamps are fitted they must be automatically switched off if the forward speed of the vehicle exceeds 10 km/h, regardless of the position of the separate switch. In this case they shall remain switched off until deliberately being switched on again.
Each seat requiring a belt must be fitted with a seat belt of the appropriate type. See annex 1
Each seat belt must bear an appropriate “e” approval mark.

Where seats are intended for use only when the vehicle is not being driven on public roads, the seats must be accompanied by a pictogram or sign clearly indicating that the seat is not to be used whilst the vehicle is in motion.
Each seat belt must be attached by an appropriate fixing and be securely fitted. (see notes 1 & 2)
There must be no damage to the seat belt structure that would affect its strength.
The seat belt lock mechanism must securely lock the belt.
The seat belt lock mechanism must be able to be released easily, both in normal use and when the belt is under load.
The retractor mechanism must be of an acceptable type and be correctly positioned to ensure the correct operation of the belt (see notes 3 & 4)
With the seat belt fastened and the seat unoccupied, retractor mechanisms must take up any excess webbing. (see note 5)
The seat belt must sit correctly across the wearers torso so as to provide effective restraint in the event of a frontal impact (see notes 3,4,6,7 & 8)
There must not be any sharp edges / objects in the seat belt area likely to cause damage to the belt.
Where an airbag is fitted in front of a passenger position, a  warning label for the airbag must be permanently fixed to the vehicle
The warning label for the airbag must be visible in front of a person about to install a rearward facing child restraint
The warning label for the airbag must be visible when the door is closed otherwise a permanent reference elsewhere that is visible at all times is required.
A harness or three point belt “effective upper anchorage” location must be at least 450mm above the reference point. See note 9 and figure 1
A lap/diagonal belt “effective upper anchorage” location must be at least 140mm from the longitudinal centre line of the seat. See note 9
The lower anchorages must be at least 350mm apart.
The lower anchorages on side facing seats must be at least 350mm apart but no further apart than 500mm (see note 10)
The  controls, tell-tales and Indicators must be identified with the correct symbols and the stated colour:  (see note 1,2, 3 and 4)
The identification symbols of controls must be on or close to the controls, tell-tales and indicators.
The identification symbols of controls must stand out clearly from the background.
The vehicle must not be fitted with other controls, tell-tales and indicators that have symbols that may be confused with the symbols listed in Tables A and B. (see note 5)
All identification symbols of controls must contrast with the background and be identifiable by the driver.
All driver controls must be able to be operated from the drivers seat.
Any information display device fitted must be able to display simultaneously the warning symbols for brake, main beam and direction indicator. (See note 5)
Any information display device fitted must provide the relevant information regarding tell – tales and indicators whenever the situation that causes them to operate arises. (See note 5)
Must repeat automatically in sequence or indicate in such a manner that it is visible to and identifiable to the driver when two or more messages are given
The vehicle must be fitted with a system capable of defrosting / demisting at least the swept area of the windscreen. (See note 1)

A system using warm air to clear the screen must employ fan assistance and ducting to direct the air onto the screen, to ensure effective operation of the defrosting system under cold weather conditions.
An electrically heated screen must provide adequate heat and distribution to ensure effective operation.
The vehicle must be fitted with a windscreen washer and wiper system to  give the driver an adequate view of the road.
All front wipers must continue to move automatically over the swept area of the windscreen.
All front wipers must have at least two sweep frequencies (see notes 1 and 2).
All front wipers must return automatically to a position of rest which is at or beyond the outer edge of the swept area.
All front wipers must be capable of being lifted from the windscreen to allow for cleaning of the windscreen.
The windscreen washer system must provide enough liquid to adequately clear the windscreen in conjunction with the wipers.
The windscreen washer system must have a reservoir capacity of at least 1 litre.

There must be no obvious fire risk associated with the heating system (e.g. flammable parts of the vehicle near to a source of heat or a likelihood of users placing objects liable to catch fire on a very hot surface).
There must be no obvious injury risk associated with the heating system (e.g. likelihood of users touching a very hot surface or hot water pipes).
If a combustion heater is fitted then it must be accompanied by documentary evidence. (See Note 1)
Any combustion heater fitted must be positioned so not likely to cause injury.
Utilising a liquid or gaseous fuel must be fitted according to the manufacturer’s instructions. (See Note 1)
A fuel filling point shared by the combustion heater and the engine must have a notice fitted instructing that the heater must be shut down before refuelling.
A combustion heater exhaust must be positioned so exhaust gases are not likely to enter the passenger compartment.

Where LPG heating systems for stationary use only are fitted. permanent warning labels/pictograms must be attached. (See note 2) :
o on the compartment where portable LPG cylinders are stored 
• and
o in close proximity to the control device for the heating system,
Where the side of the body does not meet the requirements, a side guard device must be fitted.
The side guard or body side must have its rearward edge extended to within 300mm of the tyre on the first rear axle. (see note 1 & figure 4)

The side guard or body side must have the front edge of the guard within 300 mm of the rear of the tyre on the front wheel (or second wheel if two front axles are fitted) (see note 2 & figure 4). Where stabiliser legs are fitted see Note 2.
The side guard or body side must be within 350 mm of the body line (see note 3)
The side guard or body side lower edge must be no higher than 550 mm from the ground.
The side guard or body sides must be constructed of a suitable material and must be of sufficient strength as to offer effective protection to unprotected road users (see note 4).
The side guard or body side must have a smooth or horizontally corrugated surface (see note 5)
Any external edges including corners must be rounded with a radius of at least 2.5mm
On the side guard device there must be no  projecting brackets , bolt heads or similar protrusions (see note 5 and Note 7)
The side guard or body side must be continuous in length (see note 8)
The side guard or body side must not have the rearward end more than 30mm inboard from the outermost edge of the rear tyres over at least the last 250mm of the device / body. (see figure 1).

1. Where the 300mm dimension required in standard 3 results in the forward edge of the guard being forward of the rear cab panel. The device or body side must be constructed so that the forward end is beneath the cab panel work. Where the vehicle cab is narrower than the body then the side guard may be angled to meet this requirement and be turned inwards through an angle of not more than 45 degrees (See Note 9)
Any equipment which is incorporated into the side guard must have a smooth substantially flat or horizontally corrugated outer surface (See note 5).
There must not be a gap of more than 25 mm between it and the guard or body side (see note 2, figure 3 & 5)
Where necessary the equipment must meet any required dimensional requirement as if it was part of the device.
On any equipment incorporated into the side guard there must be no projecting brackets or hinges unless sufficiently radiused from all aspects (see note 6)
Any equipment incorporated into the side guard must not have protruding bolt heads or similar projections (see note 6)
On any equipment incorporated into the side guard, any external edges and corners must be rounded with a radius of at least 2.5mm.
The side guard device must be attached securely.
The side guard device the device must consist of at least one horizontal rail (see note 3)
Where more than one horizontal rail is used, the rails must be not more than 300mm apart.
For N2 vehicles the horizontal rails must have a section height of at least  50 mm (see figure 2 A)
For N3 vehicles the horizontal rails must have a section height of at least 100 mm (see figure 2 B)
The side guard must have a forward facing edge of at least 100 mm.
The side guard must be no more than 150mm inboard from the outermost plane of the vehicle.
The side guard must not increase the overall width of the vehicle.
The side guard device must not be used for the attachment of air or hydraulic brake pipes.
Where the forward edge of the side guard lies in open space, there must be a continuous vertical member extending over the whole height of the device Note 10

Where the forward edge of the side guard lies in open space, for N2 vehicles, the  the outer and forward faces must measure at least 50 mm rearward and be turned 100 mm inwards. (see note 10 &11 & figure 2 A).

Where the forward edge of the side guard lies in open space, for N3 vehicles, the outer and forward faces must measure at least 100 mm rearward and be turned 100 mm inwards.  (see note 10 &11 & figure 2 B)
Every road wheel must be fitted with a Spray Suppression system.
All Spray Suppression material must be of an approved type. (see note 1 and 2)
All components must be secured so that they perform their function.
Mudguards must fully cover the zone immediately above, ahead and behind any part of the tyre or tyres.
Mudguards, in the case of non-steered wheels must have the lower front edge no more than 45 degrees above the horizontal line of the axle (A on figure 1)
Mudguards, in the case of steered wheels must have the lower front edge  no more than 45 degrees above the horizontal line of the axle (A on figure 1) .
Mudguards must have the lower rear edge no more than 100mm above the horizontal line of the axle (C on figure 1)
Mudguards must have Spray Suppression material fitted to the front face of the rear of the guard facing the tyre tread, complying with the dimensional requirements of figure 1 and  3
Mudguards that consist of several components must have no gaps between or within individual parts when assembled that will permit the exit of spray when the vehicle is in motion.
Where separate mudguards are fitted and where the distance between the tyres on adjacent axles does not exceed 300 mm the mudguards must also conform to the model shown in Figure 7.

Where the vehicle body forms the mudguards, (and energy absorption systems are fitted). They must cover the zone above the tyre or tyres from the front edge of the tyre to the rain flap located behind the wheel  see figure 5
Where the vehicle body forms the mudguards, (and energy absorption systems are fitted). they must have their inner faces made from or be fitted with a spray suppression material.
Any outer valence fitted to steered and self-steered wheels must have its vertical face within 100mm of the tyre wall (D on figure 2) see note 3
Any outer valence fitted to non -steered wheels must have its vertical face within 75 mm of the tyre wall (D on figure 2) see note 3
Any outer valence must have a depth of at least 45mm, at all points behind a vertical line passing through the centre of the wheel see Figure 2
Any outer valence fitted to steered wheels must have the lower edge within1.8 x tyre radius at points A, B and C as shown in Figure 4
Any outer valence fitted fitted to non - steered wheels must have the lower edge within 1.5 x tyre radius at points A,B and C as in Figure 4
Any outer valence must have no openings in them or between them and other parts of the mudguard enabling spray to emerge.

Where the body forms the mudguard over non steered or self steering wheels, and a energy absorption spray suppression system is installed outer valances must be located above each wheel of multiple axles where a rain flap is fitted between each wheel. See figure 5

Where the body forms the mudguard over non steered or self steering wheels, and a energy absorption spray suppression system is installed. outer valances must have the entire inner surface fitted with an energy-absorption spray-suppression material.
Where the body forms the mudguard over non steered or self steering wheels, and a energy absorption spray suppression system is installed outer valances must be a minimum of 100mm high.

Where the body forms the mudguard over non steered or self steering wheels, and a energy absorption spray suppression system is installed outer valances must have no openings in them or between the outer valance and the inner part of the mud guard enabling spray to emerge.

Where the body forms the mudguard over non steered or self steering wheels, and a energy absorption spray suppression system is installed outer valances must be continuous where rain flaps are not fitted behind each wheel, they must extend between the outer edge of the rain flap and a vertical plane passing through the front edge of the tyre. See figure 5
Outer Valances must have air/water separator spray-suppression devices fitted to the lower edges.
Outer Valances must have a depth of at least  45mm, at all points behind a vertical line passing through the centre of the wheel
Outer Valances fitted to steered wheels must have its lowest edge within 1.05 x tyre radius see figure 7
Outer Valances fitted to non-steered wheels must have its lowest edge within 1 x tyre radius see figure 7.
Outer Valances must have no openings in them or  between them and the mudguard enabling spray to emerge
Outer Valances, In the case of non steered wheels must have the lower front edge no more than  20 degrees above the horizontal line of the axle ( A on figure 1)
Outer Valances, In the case of steered wheels must have the lower front edge no more than 30 degrees above the horizontal line of the axle ( A on figure 1)
Where energy absorption Spray Suppression systems are installed, rain flaps must be at least equal to the full width of the tyre/s.
Where energy absorption Spray Suppression systems are installed, rain flaps must be vertical.
Where energy absorption Spray Suppression systems are installed, rain flaps must have the lower edge no more than 200 mm above the ground.  (See note 4)
Where energy absorption Spray Suppression systems are installed, rain flaps must be no more than 300 mm from a vertical plane passing through the rearmost edge of the tyre
Where energy absorption Spray Suppression systems are installed, rain flaps must have no openings between the rain flap and the lower edge of the wheel guard enabling spray to emerge.
Where energy absorption Spray Suppression systems are installed, rain flaps must have the whole face made of spray suppression material.

Where energy absorption Spray Suppression systems are installed, rain flaps must be fitted to the rearmost axle of multiple axles where distance between the tyres on adjacent axles is less than 250 mm.

Where energy absorption Spray Suppression systems are installed, rain flaps must be fitted behind each wheel of multiple axles when the distance between the tyres on adjacent axles is 250 mm or greater.
Where energy absorption Spray Suppression systems are installed, rain flaps 39. must extend to the lower part of the mud guard and comply with standards 29 to 36
Where air/water Separation Systems are installed, rain flaps must be at least equal to the full width of the tyre/s.
Where air/water Separation Systems are installed, rain flaps must be vertical.
Where air/water Separation Systems are installed, rain flaps must have no openings between the rain flap and the lower edge of the wheel guard enabling spray to emerge.
Where air/water Separation Systems are installed, rain flaps must be fitted to the rearmost axle of multiple axles where the distance between the tyres on adjacent axles is less than 250 mm.
Where air/water Separation Systems are installed, rain flaps must be fitted behind each wheel of multiple axles when the distance between the tyres on adjacent axles is 250 mm or greater.
Where air/water Separation Systems are installed, rain flaps must not be more than 200 mm from the rearmost edge of the tyre, measured horizontally.
Where air/water Separation Systems are installed, rain flaps must be at least 100 mm deep. See fig 7
Windscreens, windows, internal glazed panels and side-screens where fitted must be securely attached to the vehicle.
Windscreens, windows, internal glazed panels and side-screens where fitted must be suitable for its use. (see Table 1)
Windscreens and windows wholly or partly on either side of the driver’s seat must be “Safety Glazing” made from glass and display the relevant markings. (see note 1 and table 1)

All other windows (including sunroofs internal glazed panels and removable glass panels) and side-screens must be “Safety Glazing” (which may be made from glass, or from plastic) and display the relevant markings. (see notes 1, 2 and table 1).
Windscreens and windows wholly or partly on either side of the driver’s seat must allow a light transmission of at least 70%. (see note  3)
Each tyre fitted to the vehicle, including any spare or temporary use spare, must have the correct approval marks. (Annex 1)

The tyre must also be marked with the following information :-
Manufacturer’s name or trade mark, tyre size designation, category of use (as appropriate), speed category, load capacity index and tyre cross section. (see note 1)
Each of the tyres fitted to a vehicle, must have the same structure. (see note 2)

Each of the tyres fitted to any one axle must be of the same type. 
(see note 3)

Each tyre must have the correct load indices, speed ratings and use markings, taking into account the vehicle to which it is fitted, and the type of use i.e. load and speeds the vehicle will be subject to. (See notes 1,2,3,4 ,5 and  6 also  tables 1,2,3 & 4)

Each wheel and tyre must have sufficient room to revolve so as to ensure that it is unlikely to foul on any part, taking into consideration the suspension and steering constraints provided by the manufacturer
Tyres must be fitted in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions as indicated on the side wall of the tyre
The grooves of the tread pattern must be at least 1mm in depth through a continuous band comprising of at least ¾ of the original breadth of the tread pattern (excluding wear indicators)

The vehicle as presented must be accompanied by satisfactory evidence confirming that the vehicle is incapable of 85km/h
(See note 1)
The vehicle must be fitted with a speed limiter.

The speed limiter wiring must be secure and the speed limiter device and wiring connectors must be either sealed, or require special tools to access, so as to prevent unauthorised access to adjust the settings or interrupt the power supply.
The speed limiter plate must be securely fitted in the driver’s compartment ( see note 2 ).

The correct colour of retro reflectors must be fitted to the vehicle. (Table 1 )
The retro reflectors must be positioned to meet positional requirements of Table 1. (see Note 1)
The retro reflectors must be positioned to meet the angles of visibility requirements. of Table 1 (see Note 1)
The retro reflectors must be of the correct shape. (Table 1)
Rear reflectors must face predominately to the rear.
Full or part conspicuity markings must be fitted to vehicles more than 750kg. DGW, 6.0m long and 2.1m wide. (See Note 2)
All conspicuity marking material must be of an approved type. see note 3)
There must be at least one visable approval mark on any element of a retro-reflective marking material fitted to each face of the vehicle (o/s, n/s & rear).
The maximum gap between adjacent elements must be no greater than 50% of the smallest adjacent element (see note 4)
The lowest edge must be between 250mm and 1500mm from the ground. (see note 5)
The minimum width of the conspicuity markings must be at least 50mm.
The maximum width of the markings must be no greater than 60mm.
Rear Conspicuity Markings must be coloured either red or yellow.
Rear Conspicuity Markings must equate to at least 70% of the overall vehicle width (see note 6 & figure 5)
Rear Conspicuity Markings must be at least 200mm away from any brake mandatory light (see figure 4 A)
Side Conspicuity markings must be coloured either white or yellow.
Side Conspicuity markings must extend within 600mm of either end of the vehicle. (see figure 2)
Side Conspicuity markings 19. must equate to at least 70% of the overall vehicle length (see Notes 7 & 12 and figure 8)
Vehicle Cabs must be fitted with line markings (see Notes 8 & 12)
Where full or partial contour markings are fitted the maximum height must be as close as is practical to the top of the body. (see figure 2) (See Note 9)
Where full or partial contour markings are fitted the vertical aspect of marking must be as close to the edge as practicable. (see figure 4 B).
Where partial contour markings are fitted each side of a Tick Marking must be at least 250mm (see note 10 & figure 3)
All Rear Markers must bear a genuine permanently attached ‘e’ mark.
A minimum of one set of obligatory markers must be fitted to the vehicle (see note 11 & Table 2 )
All Rear Markers must be positioned correctly to meet the positional requirements of Table 2
They must be of the correct type ( Table 2 )

sectionDescription: End Outline, Position (Side), Stop, Side Marker & Daytime Running Lights

requiredStandards.requiredStandard: All lamps must be ‘e’ or ‘E’ marked and where applicable, bear the appropriate identity marking as listed in table 1
The front and rear position lamps, end outline marker lamps and side marker lamps, (if fitted) must be switched on and off by the operation of one switch. See Note 1
The correct number of front and rear position lamps must be fitted to the vehicle. ( Table 1 )
The front and rear position lamps must be operational.
The front and rear position lamps must only emit white light to the front / red light to the rear.
The front and rear position lamps must be positioned to meet the positional requirements of Table 1 (see note 2)
The front and rear position lamps must be positioned to meet the angles of visibility requirements of Table 1 (see note 2)
The correct number of stop lamps must be fitted to the vehicle. (Table 1)
All stop lamps must be operational.
The stop lamps must only emit red light.
They must only illuminate when the service brake is applied, and must extinguish when the service brake is released
The stop  lights must be so positioned so as to meet the positional requirements of Table 1 (see note 2)
The stop  lights must be so positioned so as to meet the angles of visibility requirements of Table 1 (see note 2)
The correct number of side marker lamps must be fitted to the vehicle. (in accordance to the positional requirements) ( see notes (3 & 4)
The side marker lights must be operational. ( see notes (3 & 4)
The side marker lights must emit an amber light. (red is acceptable if within 1 metre of the rear) ( see notes (3 & 4)
The side marker lights must be positioned to meet the positional requirements of Table 1 ( see notes (3 & 4)
The side marker lights must be positioned to meet the angles of visibility requirements of Table 1 ( see notes (3 & 4)
The correct number of end outline marker lamps must be fitted to the vehicle.( Table 1 ) see note 5 & 6)
The end outline marker lamps must be operational.see note 5 & 6)
The end outline marker lamps must only emit red light to the rear / white light to the front.see note 5 & 6)
The end outline marker lamps must be a minimum of 200mm from any position lamp.see note 5 & 6)
The end outline marker lamps must be positioned to meet the positional requirements of Table 1 (see note 1)
The end outline marker lamps must be positioned to meet the angles of visibility requirements of Table 1 (see note 1)
The correct number of daytime running lamps must be fitted to the vehicle. (Table 1)
The daytime running lamps must be operational.
The daytime running lamps must only emit white light to the front.
The daytime running lamps must be positioned to meet the positional requirements of Table 1
The daytime running lamps must be positioned to meet the angles of visibility requirements of Table 1
The daytime running lamps must extinguish automatically when headlamps are operated. (see note 7)
All direction indicator lamps must be ‘e’ or ‘E’ marked and where applicable, bear the appropriate identity marking as listed in Table 1
The direction indicator lamps must be operational.
The correct number of direction indicator lamps must be fitted to the vehicle. (table 1)
The indicators must flash at a rate of between 60 and 120 times a minute. (with all mandatory indicators working, and with the engine running if initially below the requirement)
There must be an audible or visual tell tale fitted to indicate the operation of any indicators.
All direction indicator lamps must emit amber light.
The direction indicator lamps must be positioned to meet the positional requirements of Table 1 (see note 1)
The direction indicator lamps must be positioned to meet the angles of visibility requirements of Table 1 (see note 1)
The hazard warning lamps must operate with the ignition switched on and off.
The hazard warning device must operate all of the direction indicators simultaneously.
The hazard warning device must have a telltale warning light fitted which is circuit specific.
All rear registration plate lamps must be ‘e’ or ‘E’ marked
The rear registration plate lamps must be operational.
The rear registration plate lamps must be able to be switched on and off with the front and rear position lights by operating one switch.
The rear registration plate lamps must only emit white light.
The rear registration plate lamps must be positioned to sufficiently illuminate the rear registration plate (see Note 1).
All lamps must be ‘e’ or ‘E’ marked and where applicable, bear the appropriate identity marking as listed in Table 1
All headlamps must be operational.
All obligatory and optional headlamps must be fitted as “matched pairs”.
All headlamps must emit a white light.
When on dip or main beam, headlamps must emit sufficient light to be able to illuminate the road in front of the vehicle.
The correct number of headlamps must be fitted to the vehicle (table 1)
Dipped beam headlamps must be positioned to meet the requirements of Table 1 in Section 25 of the IVA N2 - N3 Inspection Manual.
There must be a tell-tale when on main beam (See note 1)

Gas Discharge and L.E.D Headlamps must be accompanied by evidence of compliance with the technical requirements if not compliant with the following:
• is "E" or "e" marked
• dipped beam remains on when main beam is on
• is fitted with a wash system
• is fitted with an automatic headlamp self levelling system or self levelling suspension
The dipped beam image ‘kick-up’ must not be to the offside. (see note 2)
For headlamps with centres not more than 850mm from the ground, the dipped beam image horizontal cut-off must be between the horizontal 0.5% and 2% lines, i.e. the red tolerance band. (see note 2)
For headlamps with centres more than 850mm from the ground, the dipped beam image horizontal cutoff must be between the horizontal 1.25% and 2.75% lines, i.e. the blue tolerance band. (see Note 4)
The dipped beam image ‘break point’ must not be to the right of the 0% vertical line, or to the left of the vertical 2% line. (see note 2)

The vehicle must be marked with a clearly legible and indelible marking showing the setting recommended by the manufacturer for the downward inclination of the horizontal part of the cut-off of the beam pattern of the dipped-beam headlamps, that setting shall be a single figure-  ( see note 3 )
a. between 1 and 1.5 per cent if the height of the centre of the headlamp is not more than 850 mm above the ground

The vehicle must be marked with a clearly legible and indelible marking showing the setting recommended by the manufacturer for the downward inclination of the horizontal part of the cut-off of the beam pattern of the dipped-beam headlamps, that setting shall be a single figure-  ( see note 3 )
b. between 1 and 2 per cent if the height of the centre of the headlamp is more than 850 mm above the ground.
All front fog lamps must be ‘e’ or ‘E’ marked and, where applicable, bear the appropriate identity marking as listed in Table 1
The correct number of front fog lamps must be fitted to the vehicle. Table 1
The front fog lamps must be operational.
The front fog lamps must be able to be switched on only when the position lights are on and must operate independently of the dipped and main beam headlamps. (See note 1)
The front fog lamps must only emit white or yellow light.
The front fog lamps must be positioned correctly to meet the positional requirements of Table 1
The vehicle must have a suitable towing device on the front of the vehicle to allow the attachment of a rigid towing bar.
Any towing hook or eye, mounting arrangement, bracket, or surrounding vehicle structure must be able to withstand the loads expected. (see note 1 and 2)
All rear fog lamps must be ‘e’ or ‘E’ marked and where applicable, bear the appropriate identity marking as listed in Table 1
The rear fog lamps must be operational.
The correct number must be fitted to the vehicle ( Table 1 and note 1)
The rear fog lamp(s) must only illuminate when dipped beam, main beam or front fog lamps are lit (See alternatives in note 2 & 3)
The rear fog lamps must not be affected by switching on or off any other lamps (except those above)

Can be switched off independently of any other lamp, and either:
a.  may continue to be operated until the position lamps are switched off and then must remain off until deliberately switched back on

Can be switched off independently of any other lamp, and either:
b.  a warning, at least audible, additional to the mandatory tell tale is given if the ignition is switched off or the ignition key is withdrawn and the driver's door is opened whilst the rear fog lamp switch is in the 'on' position
The rear fog lamps must only emit a red light.
The rear fog lamps must be positioned correctly to meet the positional requirements of Table 1 see note 4
The rear fog lamps must be positioned correctly to meet the angles of visibility requirements of Table 1
The rear fog lamps must be fitted with an operational “tell-tale” lamp (non-flashing) visible from the driving position.
The rear fog lamps must not be operated by a brake control.
The rear fog lamps must be fitted so that the reflector is facing squarely to the rear.
Where two rear fog lamps are fitted they must form a matched pair.
Where two rear fog lamps are fitted they must operate as a matched pair
All reversing lamps must be ‘e’ or ‘E’ marked and, where applicable, bear the appropriate identity marking as listed in Table 1
The reversing lamps must be operational.
The correct number of reversing lamps must be fitted to the vehicle. (table 1)
The reversing lamps must emit white light.
They must be positioned to face the rear and meet the positional requirements of Table 1
The reversing lamps must operate by selection of reverse gear or be fitted with a telltale warning device.

Where optional lamps are fitted, the devices must be activated and deactivated manually by a separate switch used to control the front and rear position lamps, end outline marker lamps and side marker lamps,

Where optional lamps are fitted they must be automatically switched off if the forward speed of the vehicle exceeds 10 km/h, regardless of the position of the separate switch. In this case they shall remain switched off until deliberately being switched on again.
Each seat requiring a belt must be fitted with a seat belt of the appropriate type. See annex 1
Each seat belt must bear an appropriate “e” approval mark.

Where seats are intended for use only when the vehicle is not being driven on public roads, the seats must be accompanied by a pictogram or sign clearly indicating that the seat is not to be used whilst the vehicle is in motion.
Each seat belt must be attached by an appropriate fixing and be securely fitted. (see notes 1 & 2)
There must be no damage to the seat belt structure that would affect its strength.
The seat belt lock mechanism must securely lock the belt.
The seat belt lock mechanism must be able to be released easily, both in normal use and when the belt is under load.
The retractor mechanism must be of an acceptable type and be correctly positioned to ensure the correct operation of the belt (see notes 3 & 4)
With the seat belt fastened and the seat unoccupied, retractor mechanisms must take up any excess webbing. (see note 5)
The seat belt must sit correctly across the wearers torso so as to provide effective restraint in the event of a frontal impact (see notes 3,4,6,7 & 8)
There must not be any sharp edges / objects in the seat belt area likely to cause damage to the belt.
Where an airbag is fitted in front of a passenger position, a  warning label for the airbag must be permanently fixed to the vehicle
The warning label for the airbag must be visible in front of a person about to install a rearward facing child restraint
The warning label for the airbag must be visible when the door is closed otherwise a permanent reference elsewhere that is visible at all times is required.
A harness or three point belt “effective upper anchorage” location must be at least 450mm above the reference point. See note 9 and figure 1
A lap/diagonal belt “effective upper anchorage” location must be at least 140mm from the longitudinal centre line of the seat. See note 9
The lower anchorages must be at least 350mm apart.
The lower anchorages on side facing seats must be at least 350mm apart but no further apart than 500mm (see note 10)
The  controls, tell-tales and Indicators must be identified with the correct symbols and the stated colour:  (see note 1,2, 3 and 4)
The identification symbols of controls must be on or close to the controls, tell-tales and indicators.
The identification symbols of controls must stand out clearly from the background.
The vehicle must not be fitted with other controls, tell-tales and indicators that have symbols that may be confused with the symbols listed in Tables A and B. (see note 5)
All identification symbols of controls must contrast with the background and be identifiable by the driver.
All driver controls must be able to be operated from the drivers seat.
Any information display device fitted must be able to display simultaneously the warning symbols for brake, main beam and direction indicator. (See note 5)
Any information display device fitted must provide the relevant information regarding tell – tales and indicators whenever the situation that causes them to operate arises. (See note 5)
Must repeat automatically in sequence or indicate in such a manner that it is visible to and identifiable to the driver when two or more messages are given
The vehicle must be fitted with a system capable of defrosting / demisting at least the swept area of the windscreen. (See note 1)

A system using warm air to clear the screen must employ fan assistance and ducting to direct the air onto the screen, to ensure effective operation of the defrosting system under cold weather conditions.
An electrically heated screen must provide adequate heat and distribution to ensure effective operation.
The vehicle must be fitted with a windscreen washer and wiper system to  give the driver an adequate view of the road.
All front wipers must continue to move automatically over the swept area of the windscreen.
All front wipers must have at least two sweep frequencies (see notes 1 and 2).
All front wipers must return automatically to a position of rest which is at or beyond the outer edge of the swept area.
All front wipers must be capable of being lifted from the windscreen to allow for cleaning of the windscreen.
The windscreen washer system must provide enough liquid to adequately clear the windscreen in conjunction with the wipers.
The windscreen washer system must have a reservoir capacity of at least 1 litre.

There must be no obvious fire risk associated with the heating system (e.g. flammable parts of the vehicle near to a source of heat or a likelihood of users placing objects liable to catch fire on a very hot surface).
There must be no obvious injury risk associated with the heating system (e.g. likelihood of users touching a very hot surface or hot water pipes).
If a combustion heater is fitted then it must be accompanied by documentary evidence. (See Note 1)
Any combustion heater fitted must be positioned so not likely to cause injury.
Utilising a liquid or gaseous fuel must be fitted according to the manufacturer’s instructions. (See Note 1)
A fuel filling point shared by the combustion heater and the engine must have a notice fitted instructing that the heater must be shut down before refuelling.
A combustion heater exhaust must be positioned so exhaust gases are not likely to enter the passenger compartment.

Where LPG heating systems for stationary use only are fitted. permanent warning labels/pictograms must be attached. (See note 2) :
o on the compartment where portable LPG cylinders are stored 
• and
o in close proximity to the control device for the heating system,
Where the side of the body does not meet the requirements, a side guard device must be fitted.
The side guard or body side must have its rearward edge extended to within 300mm of the tyre on the first rear axle. (see note 1 & figure 4)

The side guard or body side must have the front edge of the guard within 300 mm of the rear of the tyre on the front wheel (or second wheel if two front axles are fitted) (see note 2 & figure 4). Where stabiliser legs are fitted see Note 2.
The side guard or body side must be within 350 mm of the body line (see note 3)
The side guard or body side lower edge must be no higher than 550 mm from the ground.
The side guard or body sides must be constructed of a suitable material and must be of sufficient strength as to offer effective protection to unprotected road users (see note 4).
The side guard or body side must have a smooth or horizontally corrugated surface (see note 5)
Any external edges including corners must be rounded with a radius of at least 2.5mm
On the side guard device there must be no  projecting brackets , bolt heads or similar protrusions (see note 5 and Note 7)
The side guard or body side must be continuous in length (see note 8)
The side guard or body side must not have the rearward end more than 30mm inboard from the outermost edge of the rear tyres over at least the last 250mm of the device / body. (see figure 1).

1. Where the 300mm dimension required in standard 3 results in the forward edge of the guard being forward of the rear cab panel. The device or body side must be constructed so that the forward end is beneath the cab panel work. Where the vehicle cab is narrower than the body then the side guard may be angled to meet this requirement and be turned inwards through an angle of not more than 45 degrees (See Note 9)
Any equipment which is incorporated into the side guard must have a smooth substantially flat or horizontally corrugated outer surface (See note 5).
There must not be a gap of more than 25 mm between it and the guard or body side (see note 2, figure 3 & 5)
Where necessary the equipment must meet any required dimensional requirement as if it was part of the device.
On any equipment incorporated into the side guard there must be no projecting brackets or hinges unless sufficiently radiused from all aspects (see note 6)
Any equipment incorporated into the side guard must not have protruding bolt heads or similar projections (see note 6)
On any equipment incorporated into the side guard, any external edges and corners must be rounded with a radius of at least 2.5mm.
The side guard device must be attached securely.
The side guard device the device must consist of at least one horizontal rail (see note 3)
Where more than one horizontal rail is used, the rails must be not more than 300mm apart.
For N2 vehicles the horizontal rails must have a section height of at least  50 mm (see figure 2 A)
For N3 vehicles the horizontal rails must have a section height of at least 100 mm (see figure 2 B)
The side guard must have a forward facing edge of at least 100 mm.
The side guard must be no more than 150mm inboard from the outermost plane of the vehicle.
The side guard must not increase the overall width of the vehicle.
The side guard device must not be used for the attachment of air or hydraulic brake pipes.
Where the forward edge of the side guard lies in open space, there must be a continuous vertical member extending over the whole height of the device Note 10

Where the forward edge of the side guard lies in open space, for N2 vehicles, the  the outer and forward faces must measure at least 50 mm rearward and be turned 100 mm inwards. (see note 10 &11 & figure 2 A).

Where the forward edge of the side guard lies in open space, for N3 vehicles, the outer and forward faces must measure at least 100 mm rearward and be turned 100 mm inwards.  (see note 10 &11 & figure 2 B)
Every road wheel must be fitted with a Spray Suppression system.
All Spray Suppression material must be of an approved type. (see note 1 and 2)
All components must be secured so that they perform their function.
Mudguards must fully cover the zone immediately above, ahead and behind any part of the tyre or tyres.
Mudguards, in the case of non-steered wheels must have the lower front edge no more than 45 degrees above the horizontal line of the axle (A on figure 1)
Mudguards, in the case of steered wheels must have the lower front edge  no more than 45 degrees above the horizontal line of the axle (A on figure 1) .
Mudguards must have the lower rear edge no more than 100mm above the horizontal line of the axle (C on figure 1)
Mudguards must have Spray Suppression material fitted to the front face of the rear of the guard facing the tyre tread, complying with the dimensional requirements of figure 1 and  3
Mudguards that consist of several components must have no gaps between or within individual parts when assembled that will permit the exit of spray when the vehicle is in motion.
Where separate mudguards are fitted and where the distance between the tyres on adjacent axles does not exceed 300 mm the mudguards must also conform to the model shown in Figure 7.

Where the vehicle body forms the mudguards, (and energy absorption systems are fitted). They must cover the zone above the tyre or tyres from the front edge of the tyre to the rain flap located behind the wheel  see figure 5
Where the vehicle body forms the mudguards, (and energy absorption systems are fitted). they must have their inner faces made from or be fitted with a spray suppression material.
Any outer valence fitted to steered and self-steered wheels must have its vertical face within 100mm of the tyre wall (D on figure 2) see note 3
Any outer valence fitted to non -steered wheels must have its vertical face within 75 mm of the tyre wall (D on figure 2) see note 3
Any outer valence must have a depth of at least 45mm, at all points behind a vertical line passing through the centre of the wheel see Figure 2
Any outer valence fitted to steered wheels must have the lower edge within1.8 x tyre radius at points A, B and C as shown in Figure 4
Any outer valence fitted fitted to non - steered wheels must have the lower edge within 1.5 x tyre radius at points A,B and C as in Figure 4
Any outer valence must have no openings in them or between them and other parts of the mudguard enabling spray to emerge.

Where the body forms the mudguard over non steered or self steering wheels, and a energy absorption spray suppression system is installed outer valances must be located above each wheel of multiple axles where a rain flap is fitted between each wheel. See figure 5

Where the body forms the mudguard over non steered or self steering wheels, and a energy absorption spray suppression system is installed. outer valances must have the entire inner surface fitted with an energy-absorption spray-suppression material.
Where the body forms the mudguard over non steered or self steering wheels, and a energy absorption spray suppression system is installed outer valances must be a minimum of 100mm high.

Where the body forms the mudguard over non steered or self steering wheels, and a energy absorption spray suppression system is installed outer valances must have no openings in them or between the outer valance and the inner part of the mud guard enabling spray to emerge.

Where the body forms the mudguard over non steered or self steering wheels, and a energy absorption spray suppression system is installed outer valances must be continuous where rain flaps are not fitted behind each wheel, they must extend between the outer edge of the rain flap and a vertical plane passing through the front edge of the tyre. See figure 5
Outer Valances must have air/water separator spray-suppression devices fitted to the lower edges.
Outer Valances must have a depth of at least  45mm, at all points behind a vertical line passing through the centre of the wheel
Outer Valances fitted to steered wheels must have its lowest edge within 1.05 x tyre radius see figure 7
Outer Valances fitted to non-steered wheels must have its lowest edge within 1 x tyre radius see figure 7.
Outer Valances must have no openings in them or  between them and the mudguard enabling spray to emerge
Outer Valances, In the case of non steered wheels must have the lower front edge no more than  20 degrees above the horizontal line of the axle ( A on figure 1)
Outer Valances, In the case of steered wheels must have the lower front edge no more than 30 degrees above the horizontal line of the axle ( A on figure 1)
Where energy absorption Spray Suppression systems are installed, rain flaps must be at least equal to the full width of the tyre/s.
Where energy absorption Spray Suppression systems are installed, rain flaps must be vertical.
Where energy absorption Spray Suppression systems are installed, rain flaps must have the lower edge no more than 200 mm above the ground.  (See note 4)
Where energy absorption Spray Suppression systems are installed, rain flaps must be no more than 300 mm from a vertical plane passing through the rearmost edge of the tyre
Where energy absorption Spray Suppression systems are installed, rain flaps must have no openings between the rain flap and the lower edge of the wheel guard enabling spray to emerge.
Where energy absorption Spray Suppression systems are installed, rain flaps must have the whole face made of spray suppression material.

Where energy absorption Spray Suppression systems are installed, rain flaps must be fitted to the rearmost axle of multiple axles where distance between the tyres on adjacent axles is less than 250 mm.

Where energy absorption Spray Suppression systems are installed, rain flaps must be fitted behind each wheel of multiple axles when the distance between the tyres on adjacent axles is 250 mm or greater.
Where energy absorption Spray Suppression systems are installed, rain flaps 39. must extend to the lower part of the mud guard and comply with standards 29 to 36
Where air/water Separation Systems are installed, rain flaps must be at least equal to the full width of the tyre/s.
Where air/water Separation Systems are installed, rain flaps must be vertical.
Where air/water Separation Systems are installed, rain flaps must have no openings between the rain flap and the lower edge of the wheel guard enabling spray to emerge.
Where air/water Separation Systems are installed, rain flaps must be fitted to the rearmost axle of multiple axles where the distance between the tyres on adjacent axles is less than 250 mm.
Where air/water Separation Systems are installed, rain flaps must be fitted behind each wheel of multiple axles when the distance between the tyres on adjacent axles is 250 mm or greater.
Where air/water Separation Systems are installed, rain flaps must not be more than 200 mm from the rearmost edge of the tyre, measured horizontally.
Where air/water Separation Systems are installed, rain flaps must be at least 100 mm deep. See fig 7
Windscreens, windows, internal glazed panels and side-screens where fitted must be securely attached to the vehicle.
Windscreens, windows, internal glazed panels and side-screens where fitted must be suitable for its use. (see Table 1)
Windscreens and windows wholly or partly on either side of the driver’s seat must be “Safety Glazing” made from glass and display the relevant markings. (see note 1 and table 1)

All other windows (including sunroofs internal glazed panels and removable glass panels) and side-screens must be “Safety Glazing” (which may be made from glass, or from plastic) and display the relevant markings. (see notes 1, 2 and table 1).
Windscreens and windows wholly or partly on either side of the driver’s seat must allow a light transmission of at least 70%. (see note  3)
Each tyre fitted to the vehicle, including any spare or temporary use spare, must have the correct approval marks. (Annex 1)

The tyre must also be marked with the following information :-
Manufacturer’s name or trade mark, tyre size designation, category of use (as appropriate), speed category, load capacity index and tyre cross section. (see note 1)
Each of the tyres fitted to a vehicle, must have the same structure. (see note 2)

Each of the tyres fitted to any one axle must be of the same type. 
(see note 3)

Each tyre must have the correct load indices, speed ratings and use markings, taking into account the vehicle to which it is fitted, and the type of use i.e. load and speeds the vehicle will be subject to. (See notes 1,2,3,4 ,5 and  6 also  tables 1,2,3 & 4)

Each wheel and tyre must have sufficient room to revolve so as to ensure that it is unlikely to foul on any part, taking into consideration the suspension and steering constraints provided by the manufacturer
Tyres must be fitted in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions as indicated on the side wall of the tyre
The grooves of the tread pattern must be at least 1mm in depth through a continuous band comprising of at least ¾ of the original breadth of the tread pattern (excluding wear indicators)

The vehicle as presented must be accompanied by satisfactory evidence confirming that the vehicle is incapable of 85km/h
(See note 1)
The vehicle must be fitted with a speed limiter.

The speed limiter wiring must be secure and the speed limiter device and wiring connectors must be either sealed, or require special tools to access, so as to prevent unauthorised access to adjust the settings or interrupt the power supply.
The speed limiter plate must be securely fitted in the driver’s compartment ( see note 2 ).
The speed limiter plate must be clearly and indelibly marked with the speed at which the limiter has been set (the speed may be set in mph or km/h) (see note 3)
The vehicle must not exceed the maximum authorised dimensions for width and length. (See note 1).
In the case of a vehicle subject to Plating, the vehicle or axle weights (as presented) must not exceed the maximums authorised for the Plating certificate.
In the case of a vehicle not subject to Plating, the vehicle or axle weights (as presented) must not exceed the maximums marked on the Statutory Plate prescribed in section 18 of this manual.

Where the Maximum permissible trailer towing weight exceeds 3500kg or the vehicle is equipped to tow a semi-trailer, it must be verified that the vehicle has a facility to operate power brakes on the trailer.

If a vehicle is fitted with one or more loadable axles, satisfactory evidence must be provided stating that under all driving conditions, the axle will lower to the ground automatically when the front axle or the nearest axle of a group of axles is loaded.

The motor vehicle must be able to manoeuvre for a complete circular trajectory of 360 degrees within the defined area (with the exception of the protruding parts prescribed for the vehicle width shown in Annex 1)  (See figure 1)

Any part of the vehicle must not move outside of the vertical plane by more than 0.8 metres. For vehicles with retractable axles in the lifted position, or loadable axles in the un-laden condition, the figure of 0,80 m is replaced by 1,00 m. 
(For vehicles with an axle-lift device this requirement should be checked to both requirements shown above  applies with the axle(s) in the running and lifted positions ) (See figure 2)
The vehicle must not exceed the maximum authorised dimensions for width and length.

In the case of a vehicle not subject to Plating, the vehicle or axle weights (as presented) must not exceed the maximums marked on the Statutory Plate prescribed in section 18 of this manual. (See note 1)

Where the Maximum permissible trailer towing weight exceeds 3500kg or the vehicle is equipped to tow a semi-trailer, it must be verified that the vehicle has a facility to operate power brakes on the trailer.

If a vehicle is fitted with one or more loadable axles, satisfactory evidence must be provided stating that under all driving conditions, the axle will lower to the ground automatically when the front axle or the nearest axle of a group of axles is loaded.

A mascot, emblem or other ornamental object must retract or detach when a reasonable force is applied, and leave a base or mounting free from sharp edges that does not protrude from the surface by more than 10mm.

All ‘hard’ parts contactable with a 100mm sphere, which form an external surface or protrude 5mm or more from the external surface must have a radius of curvature of at least 2.5mm. (see notes 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, and  7)
Protrusions less than 5mm contactable with a 100mm sphere must have blunted edges
Wheel arches must be ‘turned inwards’, or have a radius of curvature of at least 2.5mm.
The edges of running boards and steps must be rounded (the top surface of the step is exempt)

They must be operational
The correct number must be fitted to the trailer ( Table 1 )

Where two rear fog lamps are fitted they must operate as a matched pair.

A Combustion heater must be positioned so that it is not likely to cause injury

A Combustion heater must give no obvious fire risk associated with the heating system (e.g. flammable parts of the vehicle near to a source of heat or a likelihood of users placing objects liable to catch fire on a very hot surface).
A Combustion heater must be positioned so that it is not likely to cause injury
A Combustion heater must be positioned so exhaust gases are not likely to enter the accommodation / exhibition compartment

Where a LPG heating system is fitted for stationary use only, permanent warning labels/pictograms must be attached. (See note 2)  in close proximity to the control device for the heating system
Where the side of the body does not meet the requirements, a side guard device must be fitted. (See note 1)
The device or body side must have its rearward edge extended to within 300mm of the tyre on the first rear axle. (see note 2 & figure 1)
On a draw bar trailer the front edge of the guard must be no more than 500mm to the rear of the rearmost part of the tyre on the wheel immediately forward of the guard. (See note 2)

On a centre axle trailer the front edge of the guard must extend no further than the front of the bodywork, (if any), or the chassis where the drawbar connects and must not affect normal manoeuvrability of the trailer.

On a semi-trailer the front edge of the guard must be no more than 250mm to the rear of the centre line of the support legs, but in any case never more than 2.7m behind the centre of the king pin. (see figure 1)
The device or body side must be within 350 mm of the body line (see note 3)
The device or body side lower edge must be no higher than 550 mm from the ground.
The device or body sides must be constructed of a suitable material and must be of sufficient strength as to offer effective protection to unprotected road users (see note 1)
The device or body side must have a smooth or horizontally corrugated surface (see note 4)
Any external edges and corners must be rounded with a radius of at least 2.5mm
There must be no  projecting brackets , bolt heads or similar protrusions (see note 5 and Note 9)
1The device or body side must be continuous in length (see note 6)
The device or body side must not have the rearward end more than 30mm inboard from the outermost edge of the rear tyres over at least the last 250mm of the device / body
Any equipment which is incorporated into the side guard must have a smooth substantially flat or horizontally corrugated outer surface (See note 4)
There must not be a gap of more than 25 mm between any equipment incorporated into the side guard and the side guard or body side. (see note 7, figure 2 & 4)
Where necessary, the equipment incorporated into the side guard must meet any required dimensional requirement as if it was part of the device.
Where necessary, the equipment incorporated into the side guard must have no projecting brackets or hinges unless suitably radiused from all aspects  (see note 5)
Any equipment incorporated into the side guard must not have protruding bolt heads or similar protrusions (see note 5)
On any equipment incorporated into the side guard, any external edges and corners must be rounded with a radius of at least 2.5mm.
The device must be attached securely
The device must consist of  at least one horizontal rail (see note 3)
Where more than one horizontal rail is used, the rails must be not more than 300mm apart.
O3 trailers the horizontal rails must have a section height of at least  50 mm (figure 3A)
O4 trailers the horizontal rails must have a section height of at least 100 mm (figure 3B)
The side guard must have a forward facing edge of at least 100 mm.
The side guard must be no more than 150mm inboard from the outermost plane of the trailer
The side guard must not increase the overall width of the trailer.
The side guard device must not be used for the attachment of air or hydraulic brake pipes.
Where the forward edge lies in open space (See note 10) there must be a continuous vertical member extending over the whole height of the device

Where the forward edge lies in open space (See note 10) then for O4 trailer, the outer and forward faces must measure at least 100 mm rearward and be turned 100 mm inwards. (see note 8 and figure 3)
Every road wheel must be fitted with a Spray Suppression system.
All Spray Suppression material must be of an approved type. (see note 1 and 2)
All components must be secured so that they perform their function.
Mudguards must fully cover the zone immediately above, ahead and behind any part of the tyre or tyres.
Mudguards, in the case of non steered wheels must have the lower front edge no more than 45 degrees above the horizontal line of the axle ( A on figure 1)
Mudguards, in the case of steered wheels must have the lower front edge  no more than 45 degrees above the horizontal line of the axle ( A on figure 1)
Mudguards must have the lower rear edge no more than 100mm above the horizontal line of the axle (C on figure 1)must have the lower rear edge no more than 100mm above the horizontal line of the axle.
Mudguards must have Spray Suppression material fitted to the front face of the rear of the guard facing the tyre tread, complying with the dimensional requirements of figure 1. and  3
Mudguards that consist of several components must have no gaps between or within individual parts when assembled that will permit the exit of spray when the trailer is in motion.
Where separate mudguards are fitted, where the distance between the tyres on adjacent axles does not exceed 300 mm the mudguards must also conform to the model shown in Figure 7.

Where the trailer body forms the mudguards, (and energy absorption systems are fitted) suppression must cover the zone above the tyre or tyres from the front edge of the tyre to the rain flap located behind the wheel  see figure 5
Where the trailer body forms the mudguards, (and energy absorption systems are fitted) must have their inner faces made from or be fitted with a spray suppression material.

Any outer valence (with energy absorption Spray Suppression systems installed) fitted to steered and self-steered wheels must have its vertical face within 100mm of the tyre wall (D on figure 2) see note 3
Any outer valence (with energy absorption Spray Suppression systems installed) fitted to non -steered wheels must have its vertical face within 75 mm of the tyre wall (D on figure 2) see note 3

Any outer valence (with energy absorption Spray Suppression systems installed) must have a depth of at least 45mm, at all points behind a vertical line passing through the centre of the wheel see Figure 2
Any outer valence (with energy absorption Spray Suppression systems installed fitted to steered wheels must have the lower edge within1.8 x tyre radius at points A,B and C as shown in Figure 4
Any outer valence (with energy absorption Spray Suppression systems installed) fitted to non - steered wheels must have the lower edge within1.5 x tyre radius at points A,B and C as in Figure 4
Any outer valence (with energy absorption Spray Suppression systems installed) must have no openings in them or between them and other parts of the mudguard enabling spray to emerge.

Where the body forms the mudguard over non steered or self steering wheels, outer valances must be located above each wheel of multiple axles where a rain flap is fitted between each wheel. See figure 5
Where the body forms the mudguard over non steered or self steering wheels, outer valances must have the entire inner surface fitted with an energy-absorption spray-suppression material.
Where the body forms the mudguard over non steered or self steering wheels, outer valances must be a minimum of 100mm high .

Where the body forms the mudguard over non steered or self steering wheels, outer valances must have no openings in them or between the outer valance and the inner part of the mud guard enabling spray to emerge.

Where the body forms the mudguard over non steered or self steering wheels, outer valances must be continuous where rain flaps are not fitted behind each wheel, they must extend between the outer edge of the rain flap and a vertical plane passing through the front edge of the tyre. See figure 5
Outer Valances must have air/water separator spray-suppression devices fitted to the lower edges.
Outer Valances must have a depth of at least 45mm, at all points behind a vertical line passing through the centre of the wheel
Outer Valances fitted to steered wheels must have their lowest edge within 1.05 x tyre radius see figure 7
Outer Valances fitted to non-steered wheels fitted to non-steered wheels must have its lowest edge within 1 x tyre radius see figure 7
Outer Valances must have no openings in them or  between them and the mudguard enabling spray to emerge
